reviewText:
Price (regular): $29.99 ($39.99 for deluxe)
Price (lowest): $7.49 (75% off)
My overall rating: 9.5/10Easily one of my favorite games of all time.

Value: 9/10Most other games this age are already down to $20, however the singleplayer is a lot longer than most other action/shooter games, making it well worth the price.

Singleplayer: 10/10Amazing singleplayer. Capturing outposts is probably the best part. There are over 30 spread over the massive map. The main story has some pretty good action too. Plus there is hunting, racing, and assassination side missions and a lot of other things that are a lot of fun.

Co-op: 5/10 (2-4 players)Co-op has some serious issues. When the match tries to launch it almost always crashes or freezes when loading. Due to this you wont be able to find players unless you are playing with friends. When it works it is decent but doesnt have the openness that makes far cry great. Update: co-op has been working better lately.

Multiplayer: 6.5/10The multiplayer is actually pretty good, but a little generic. Doesn't have enough players to reach its full potential though.

Content: 9.5/10Both the co-op and multiplayer are pretty basic, but the singleplayer makes up for it. You of course have the story and outposts, but there is also tons of ruins and caves to be explored for relics and loot, side missions, trials, races, dlc missions, and even knife throwing and poker.

Length: 10/10An average playthrough of the singleplayer will take you roughly 30 hours, doing the main storyline capturing all the outposts and doing most of the side missions.

Story: 8/10The story really tries to be great and in some ways it is but also is a little flat. You and your friends are having the time of your life until getting caught by slavers on a remote island. You escape and have to save your friends and liberate the natives from the pirates in the process.

Gameplay: 10/10Very good, open gameplay. Most situations you can choose to attack however you like. Climb any mountain for a good vantage point with a sniper rifle, use stealth with a bow and using knife takedowns, attack head on with an lmg, or charge in with a truck with c4 planted on it.

With freinds: 6/10The co-op and multiplayer are pretty fun with friends but doesnt have a lot of substance.

Graphics: 9/10Good graphics, very good considering the scale of the game.

Physics: 9.5/10Maybe not as smooth walking around a small area and shooting a few people as call of duty, but all in all the physics are a lot better than just about any other game. Driving really feels good. Good fire physics, you can light large areas of brush with a flamethrower.

Performance: 9/10Works good for the most part. Can easily play it on max setting with my laptop, core i7 4810mq @ 2.80 GHz (turbo to 3.80 GHz) 12gbs ram and gtx870m 3gbs dedicated. Haven't had any notable issues or bugs.

Sound: 8/10Sound is good but maybe a little rough here and there.

Polished: 8/10Nothing majorly wrong with it but it does have the usual trees growing through rocks and animals spawning inside stuff.

Atmosphere: 8.5/10The vast landscape gives you a good immersive feel but could be better if they didn't have so much of the same plants making it all feel the same.

Objectives: 7/10Objectives are pretty basic. Pretty much go fight through these people and do (insert objective here). Some are a little more in depth.

Clarity: 9/10No problems with knowing where to go or what to do. The story line is linear and very easy to follow.

World: 9.5/10Unparalleled world. Massive world with large mountains, caves, ruins, shanty towns, vast foliage, ocean, and tons of wildlife to try and kill you. Although most of the landscape has the same trees and plants so a lot of it looks the same.

Characters: 8/10The characters are interesting. The antagonists really make you want to kill them. All the characters are just a little thin but still good.

UI: 6.5/10The menus are pretty poor. Pulling up your map is really slow. All other menus are in the escape menu which is pretty slow and not that great to navigate. Plus there's Uplay which is horrible.

Controls: 9/10Mostly standard controls. Not my favorite layout but close enough I didn't feel the need to change anything.

Freedom: 10/10As much freedom as you could ask for. You can ignor your current mission to go off capturing outpost, doing side mission, or just go for a nature hike.

Influence: 2.5/10The story itself is very linear. Only choice in the game is the ending and what happens after.

Settings: 9/10Four difficulty setting so good for most any skill level. Average control options.

Character progression: 6/10Sometimes feels like they resticked what you can do at the beginning instead of allowing you to do more later on.

Weapon selection: 9/10Has plenty of weapons. Handguns, SMGs, assault rifles, shotguns, LMGs, sniper rifles, launchers, explosives, and specials. Over 30 total, though some feel similar.

Customization: 7/10Most weapons can be modded. Higher level guns can have up to 3 mods. Mods incude extended mags, silencers, and several types of sights, though most guns are limited on which mods are available. Almost all weapons can be painted.

AI: 8.5/10For the most part the ai is fairly intelegent. Considering what they have to do in an open world unrelated to a story, it's very good. Though this causes a few quirks.

Up to date: 9/10Only came out at the end of 2012 and there isn't any notable aging to the game. Not lacking anything that newer games might have.

Replayability: 8.5/10The story doesnt give incentive replay it, but since you can whatever you like however you like, the rest of the game has a lot of replay value.

Pace: 8.5/10For such a long game the balance between length and action is very good. You can go straight to the next mission, rush through a few outposts, or take your time doing everything at your own pace.

Repetitiveness: 8/10If you were to just walk up with an assault rifle everytime it would probably get very repetitive, but change up your approach everytime and it won't be much at all.

Realism: 8.5/10It has some good aspects and a few poor ones when it comes to how realistic it is. Even compared to other games the amount of people you are able to kill is a little ridiculous. It has some supernatural elements which isn't bad but they are a little lame and seem to be inspired by acid trips. Other than that it's actually got good physics and overall better than most games.

DLC: 5/10The downloadable content is all pretty mediocre. A few independent short story missions that are okay, some co-op and multiplayer content, and a few other things that are all insignificant.

Achievements: 6/1050 achievements but only on Uplay not Steam, and 6 are for co-op making them near impossible. The rest of the achievements are great. Good amount and some challenging but nothing too hard.

Trading cards: N/ADoesn't have Steam badges/trading cards.

Series improvement: 10/10Far Cry 2 was a good game, however has aged a lot and lacked in a few aspects. Far Cry 3 did a great job at improving and made a very well rounded, good performing game.

Originality: 10/10Bottom line is that no other game is very much like Far Cry. Maybe slightly similar to games like Just Cause or some RPGs and it may have some Tomb Raider elements but not enough that its overall gameplay is at all the same as anything else.

reviewText:
So, here's my final verdict for Far Cry 3. Well, I'm currently doing my fourth playthrough of the game (been doing every difficulty) And I still enjoy it just as much as when the first time I played it. I guess that tells you a little bit if the gameplay/story is good, if not, let me go deeper into it.


Story:

Without spoiling anything, I'm going to briefly tell you what the game is about. You're jason, some guy who was on a nice trip with his friends until everything went downhill. You find yourself caged with your brother on an island full of crazy pirates.
Then you have Vaas, in my opinion one of the coolest villains ever in video game history. Actually, I'm not gonna tell you anything about him, why don't you just get the game and take a look yourself? Throughout the game, you become more powerful, powerful enough to decide you want to take down the people who run the Islands. Are you able to do so, though? You can only find out yourself. There are 2 different endings.


Gameplay:


Far Cry 3 offers a LOT. It's not your regular shooter, no, It's more like.. Hmm, It's quite hard to say really. On Rook Island, you can find plants, animals and useful gear to upgrade your Jason with. You do this by crafting either ammo pouches, medicine, or useful items that can make hunting a little easier. There's quite a lot of different weapons to find/buy, and they all seem to be pretty damn well done. I didn't find any guns that seem underpowered. A single playthrough of the game should take you well over 20 hours, maybe even 30, if you take your time to explore the amazing landscape and secrets the island has to offer. I don't want to go on too much, so I'm just gonna leave you guys to decide wether or not to get the game. Would I recommend it? YES. Absolutely YES. There's nothing you can go wrong with here. Oh, before I miss it, this game support MODS. If you want more of a challenge, try out Ziggy's Mod. It makes the game a lot more challenging by removing the hud, spotting and free weapons.


My final verdict for Far Cry 3 is a 9/10. Only because it wasn't a perfect game, I still wish the multiplayer could be worked on a bit more, but the 9 goes to the singleplayer alone. Thanks for reading my review, and I hope you'll get your hands on this amazing game. :)

reviewText: The sandbox world has just about everything you could ask for. The only thing I can think of that is missing is an actual volcano, otherwise the two islands that make up this game's playable area are everything you'd expect on a tropical island. The addition of wildlife in this game adds such an aspect of realism, I found myself stalking a tiger just to watch him take down a deer or goat. reviewText:
Far Cry 3 is one of those open-world games that actually makes you FEEL you'd WANT to explore the Rook Islands with its varied wild flora AND fauna (hostile or indifferent), as well as the various enemies (pirates or privateers) and with the Rakyat assisting at times. The story missions are quite a lot of fun, and if you level up properly none of them are very difficult (i.e. do the stealth kills and try to take down outposts undetected to get extra XP for the skills).

You started out as a party guy Jason Brody, who can't do anything. Your brother Grant was the ex-Army, and somehow you ended up captured on this island held by pirates and right in the INTRO sequence your brother got killed and your mad dash to freedom ended up with you diving over a waterfall, but you lived, and you woke up in a village, and handed your first mission... and a wimply pistol... get up this tower on top of the hill, and activate it.

From there on, you steadily progress from a wimpy adrenaline junky to a fearsome killing machine capable of mowing down squads of professional mercenaries with LMG or assault rifle, hit wings off a fly at 100 yards with a sniper rifle, blade dance with professional knife fighters, stealth kill like a ninja, as you liberate the Rook Islands from two megalomaniacs, Vaas, and his boss, Hoyt, while recovering your friends one by one.

The islands are beautiful, and the animals behave independently of you. Goats and Buffalos and pigs and more wander the landscape, and predators like bears, leopards, even tigers wander the wild hunting them, and if you get in the way, you as well. In the ocean there are bull sharks and regular fish, and in the swamps there are crocodiles. Yes, it's a ton of fun exploring the place. There are small villages, pirate and merc outposts (that you can liberate... by killing everybody), unoccupied villages that were sites of atrocities, more radio towers you can deactivate, plus for the obssessive collectors, various artifacts to collect, such as 120 relics from the past cultures (including one from Chinese history!) letters from the Japanese WW2 occupation (plenty of bodies left around), memory cards left in outposts detailing the sordid narc industry links of Rook Island, as well as different animals and plants (they go in the survival handbook).

There are also untold number of caves, underground passages, leading to totally unknown areas deep within the bowels of the island that makes you wonder if you're playing Tomb Raider. :D  Indeed, the radio towers and many other sequences do require a bit of jumping and climbing to accomplish.

Even on the surface, there are random things happening. Friendly and enemy jeeps patrol the routes. Enemy soldiers will patrol, and sometimes, force march prisoners / slaves on the road. You may engage, or not as you see fit, but they are excellent source of XPs, as valid as any one. And animals do roam the island, as it is wild out there.

There are plenty of side missions, some of which are handed out by locals, like help find my daughter

reviewText:
Far cry 3's best moments are also some of my best moments in gaming, I'll leave my love for this game aside and try be fair evaluating it's aspects.
First of all, you can feel the Far cry 2 engine here, similar animations and gunplay, but its definitley improved.
Graphics are pretty, shaders could have been a little less saturated for a more realistic look, but its an art direction choice, still beautiful anyway! I found a few bugs, objects revealing geometry, shadows loading in a weird way and black textures appearing on roads whenever I was nearby, It breaks immersion but don't compromise the fun.
Gameplay is fluid, animations are well made, guns feel powerful and there are plenty to choose from your loadout, you can craft boosts from herbs you harvest in the jungle, use a bow that add's a Hunter feel that we all love, and take a stealthy approach if that's your thing, that was something I wasn't sure it would work out well but It did, I finished the game using the knife and bow mostly.
Performance is pretty fair, the game runs well if you have a good machine and still pretty even on medium specs, I played this with an GTS450 on medium and then maxed out with a 650ti Boost, running with 40fps most of the time.
Story and characters are quite memorable, did I ever tell you the definition of good character design? you got it.
After you finish the story you still have activities to complete, hunt & assassination missions, outposts to clear,  towers to climb and work your magic to unlock new weapons, it's a very rewarding game and it has lore on every item you acquire. I still have to try the co-op, if you're reading this maybe we should give it a try!?

tl;dr
+ Open world
+ Memorable story and characters
+ Gun customization and variety
+ Stealth is an option
+ Replay value
+ Burning weed with Skrillex‚Ñ¢

- Minor graphic bugs sometimes
- Requires Ubi-Launcher
- DLC is Irrelevant and Skippable
- Dead multiplayer

reviewText:
Exceptional open-world shooter with a dark twist
Far Cry 3 was developed by Ubisoft Montr√©al & Shanghai and published late 2012 to great ciritcal acclaim. I played it only recently (early 2015), but even though some years old, this game feels like it was made recently. As the third installment in the famous Far Cry franchise, it continues upon the open-world orientated gameplay establised by Far Cry 2, while fixing almost all of the problems that game had and offering a feel and way of playing all of its own.

The game makes one identify to a degree with Jason Brody, the playable protagonist who is taken captive together with his friends on a tropical island by a gang of pirates lead by someone called Vaas. The opening sequence of the game, from the initial cutscene with the rather vainly partying friends up to the first encounter with Vaas and the escape from his claws, stands out as a classic way of making clear what a game is all about. Vaas is a sinister character, as dark and evil as one could imagine, and more. His fascination with utter violence and the madness of the human mind offers some memorable gaming moments, that made me stare at my screen in utter disbelief and will stay with me for a long time.
Jason Brody starts out as a rather unsure would-be-hero, who is shocked whenever he sees someone killed, and who is very reluctant to kill himself. But his encounter with the sheer evil of Vaas and his fellow criminals, gradually turns him into a killing machine, with only one goal: to free his friends, and ultimately seek revenge. The game cleverly underscores this development by offering some role-playing element: finishing missions or killing enemies grants experience points and levels you up so that you can acquire several abilities which help to overcome obstacles more easily. While the game is rather challenging during its first hours, with raising in level and acquiting more special abilities and better weapons it gets easier, which helps to get the idea of turning into a mean killing machine rather well.

Apart from Jason Brody and Vaas, Far Cry 3 contains several interesting and even unique characters along with three factions" spread out on two distinct islands. There are too many characters to mention them all

reviewText: Far Cry 3 was my introduction to the Far Cry franchise. Now I‚Äôm not a huge fan of first person shooters (FPS) but there are some goods and this is one of them. Where you hunt down relics of the ancient ancestors that lived on the island.  See and feel the effects of World War 2 on this Pacific island.  Truly a world where anything goes and does happen.  The story happens in a nonlinear fashion but as you progress you will see how it all fits together and how this forges your champion Jason Brody.  And the nice thing about the far cry series is each game is its own other then being an open world shooter you don't need to play them in an particular order.  If your looking for a game you can run through swamps, jungles, and mountains you found it don't get me wrong it is no Skyrim on that size but it will take you a good 10+ to get from one side to another.  But if you are one of the people that has to everything in a game you can easily get 60+ hours of play time.  The biggest downside of the game is your friends you are rescuing how they seem unaffected by this island.  The graphics are awe inspiring and the cut scenes will have your heart racing especially.....* NO SPOILERS*  Get the game and find out for yourself.

reviewText:
Far Cry 3 is a first-person shooter action game created by Ubisoft Montreal in 2012.

The player, Jason Brody, skydives with friends and ends up on an island full of pirates and natives called Rakyat that are in conflict . Jason escapes but is unconscious. An inhabitant of the island, a Rakyat called Denis rescues him and performs a tattoo that gives Jason powers. This is the first step on his journey to become a warrior. From there he must find and free his friends.

The game is a sandbox, and the main story is just a little part of it, the player is free to make a huge amount of fun activities. Play racing , throw knives , face challenges, hunt animals , free towers and regain positions held by pirates. The game has the graphic quality of a first person shooter with the freedom of an RPG .

The graphics engine is called Dunia Engine. The graphic quality is very good , similar to Crysis, awesome for being a Sandbox. Far Cry3 was one of the best and most complete games of 2012. Extremely funny and fascinating.

It is a worthy successor to Far Cry , well above the poor Far Cry 2 . A true wonder for lovers of external environments and forests in games.

The game was released for PC , PS3 and XBOX 360. The PC version has superior graphics and a powerful graphics card with DirectX 11 is seriously recommended.

And Trisha the Warrior ..... ohh, I can't tell you how hot she is.

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rABzXCF2AHs

Many people dream of finding themselves posted on a white sand beach on an island in the pacific, sipping a tropical drink and flicking tenacious hermit crabs from their belongings. If you are ambitious and a bit stupid, like Jason Brody and company, then you may try to spice up the proceedings with a bit of skydiving. So begins, Far Cry 3, a game about a bunch of American yuppies on a vacation that has seriously gone wrong. Back and 2004 Far Cry's open world gameplay was revolutionary, roaming tropical islands slaying mercs and trigens created quite a splash before being encumbered by the tsunami that was Doom 3 and Half Life 2 later the same year. With S.T.A.L.K.E.R being the only other franchise to successfully merge open world shooting with light RPG elements, and Crytek moving toward more traditional levels for their Crysis games, the market is wide open for Ubisoft's vacation from hell simulator.

While living it up in Bangkok in order to celebrate his younger brother obtaining his pilot's license, Jason Brody and crew make the ill fated decision to go skydiving. They happen to land on an island infested with pirates and they are taken hostage where they are being primed to be sold into slavery. Jason escapes and meets some locals who aid him in his quest to find his friends and escape since they see it as an opportunity to have Jason liberate their island. It's a tale that's part Deliverance, part Indiana Jones with a dash of the drug abusing hijinx in Alice in Wonderland. Far Cry 3's narrative benefits from a number of eccentric personalities like Spike Lee's Island dwelling clone Dennis, gaming's most possessive and insane ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• Citra,  and doctor who indulgences in enough mind altering substances to make Hunter S. Thompson blush. Topping off the insane cast of character's is Vaas, the leader of the pirates. Unfortunately, Far Cry 3 blunders Final Fantasy VIII style by shifting the focus away from Vaas partway through the game and substituting a far less engaging and charismatic villain. The well worn theme of civilized man reverting to a more primitive state to survive in a primitive environment is a bit hamfisted as every few missions has Jason returning to his girlfriend so that she can keep pointing out how he has changed... Also, the plot is tainted by a white messiah complex. For some reason it seems that the legions of native warriors are not the equal of one white guy with a crappy tribal tattoo and a desire to save his friends.

While Jason is not a soldier or gun toter by trade, he quickly warms up to carrying a firearm and explosives in order to liberate his friends. Missions give Jason the opportunity to earn money and experience which he can use to augment his skills and buy new weapons and attachments. Slaughtering the wildlife also gives Jason the opportunity to craft new storage for ammo, explosives and money. The flora can be harvested in order to create medicines that allow Jason to heal and enhance his senses. While all of these crafting opportunities help make use of the large game world and the critters that inhabit it, it also means that the game can have an agonizing start. Initially, Jason can only carry one weapon and very little ammo meaning that exploration grinds to a halt after only a few minutes before needing to resupply. You will want to craft new holsters to hold more weapons and compartments for more ammo immediately. Torching bears with flame throwers, using grenades as depth charges to kill crocodiles and sharks and running kommodo dragons over with jeeps does provide a depraved and perverted form of entertainment.

Also populating the world are radio towers that have to be scaled in order to unlock a section of the map a la Assassin's Creed and Outposts that need to be cleared out in order to keep those pesky pirates from roaming certain regions of the map. Both the towers and the outposts have unique layouts and terrain that distinguishes one from another but never the less you will fall into a pattern of uncovering the map then liberating the outposts as you progress deeper into the game which becomes terribly repetitive. The wildlife in Far Cry 3 doesn't exist solely for the benefit of adding pouches to Jason's belt either. Animals are often found in cages in enemy outposts where they can be freed to create havok. It just so happens that pirates are much easier to kill when they are trying to save one of their buddies from getting murdered by an angry cassowary. While Far Cry 3 provides weaponry and attachments that encourage stealth, it's also possible to raid outposts full shock and awe style with guns on full auto chucking grenades like Eli Manning throws interceptions. Both methods have their thrills but almost invariably players will lean on their overpowered weaponry late in the game to steam roll the opposition. The extra 1,000 experience just isn't worth the time saved by storming an outpost Rambo style.

Fortunately, Far Cry 3's main missions provide a much needed reprieve from the repetition of radio tower climbing and outpost raiding. Missions often take Jason to instanced areas like abandoned Japanese bunkers from World War 2 and ancient temples with Indiana Jones style perils. Even a handful of late game filler missions offer some riotous thrills and enough fireworks to please even the most jaded action gamer. Forced stealth sections are staged in such a way they they are painfully easy however and some really irritating quick time events rear their ugly heads and detract from the experience. Like wise a mid game string of quests that have you raiding ancient temples to reassemble a magic compass throw the tone of the game off. If all of the aforementioned content isn't satisfactory to you there are also extra missions that have you killing animals and special targets with a specified weapon, score-based Rakyat challenges and some small errands given to you by NPCs. It's a rather robust singleplayer that will last most gamers 15 to 20 hours.

The Far Cry 3 experience doesn't stop with it's campaign however. There are six co-op missions that tell the story of a group of rough around the edges characters who have been duped out of their money by the Pirates and are pursuing them on Rook Island. The narrative is sparse and the gameplay does little to really take advantage of having three friends playing alongside you. You earn experience that unlocks upgrades that can also be used for the competitive multiplayer suit. Multiplayer is a collection of variations of classic multiplayer modes like Team Deathmatch, King of the Hill, capture the flag and domination. The multiplayer does little nothing to take advantage of some of Far Cry's more unique features. Don't expect your foes to be mauled to death by tigers or to be able to jump into a vehicle to make a hasty escape. Odds are, players will get more time out of the main campaign.

reviewText:
Far Cry 3 is wonderful in terms of the environment and graphics (stunning visuals!). There are not many games that have such an enjoyable system of roaming around the map, hunting, driving, swimming, flying etc. The fight is often easy, but fun. The singleplayer experience is quite tense and full of fast-paced action (car chases, bomb escapes, burning houses, helicopter flights, ambushes... a lot of good points). There are even some stealth aspects, you may conquer the outposts in a silent-assassin way and I admit - it gave me a lot of good gameplay experience, especially with later knife skills. Aside from the outposts you'll see it's just a nicely scripted shooter often with no practical use for silent approach :)
So, why do I give it a negative mark? Let me explain in a few points...
If you spend some time on doing side miniquests and hunt, you get really powerful - I quickly got to point when I maxed my skill tree, had bought everything I could and still had overflow of money. Of course, it's up to you how far you go with exploring the map, so let's say it's not a minus, more like neutral remark.
The game has a very dark feeling in it. A lot of despair, loneliness, brutality, often without reason. Sometimes the protagonist make extremely stupid, unbelievable decisions. Your enemies (and some allies...) are psychopatic maniacs. There are a lot of drug themes. I know a lot of these are justified by the plot, but every time I moved a bit forward in game (not counting map exploration), I felt sad and dull. (game music even amplify it) Watch out, if you feel pesimist, probably this game might just make you feel worse...
Whole drug aspect - not only there's too much of it for my taste, I also feel that the game creators took it as a handy shortcut for fixing loose plot points. I don't want to leave spoilers here, so let's just say that replacing a few proper fights with drug induced visions (and then, magically, your character somehow won everything!) is very cheap. You see a problem but don't solve it, just hop into narcotic projection, see some ghosts and delusions, get back to 'real' world and everything is already done. Yay...
Although many parts of the campaign were enjoyable (especially action scenes mentioned before), the ending itself was so disgusting/stupid (I chose good" ending
date: "bad" one was even worse) that it totally threw me off this game. Honestly
recommended: I haven't played it anymore since I finished the main plot.\nMultiplayer - I managed to unlock everything before I finished singleplayer and then

reviewText:
Far Cry 3 is an open world first-person shooter published by Ubisoft Entertainment. It is the next installment of Far Cry series after Far Cry 2.

Far Cry 3 gameplay, it has open world, it has small RPG element, and it has one of the best villain character ever. In my opinion Far Cry 3 open world feature is almost similar to Assassin's Creed where you have to climb a radio tower, interact some sort of panel to explore some area on the world around the tower. In Far Cry 3 you don't just get to shoot somebody and run. You can buy and upgrade weapons in store, level up getting new tattoos which conveniently giving you new abilities such as walk faster or something, also, there are some upgrades that require you to hunt for animals hide or plants. The best part is, when you shoot a tiger, it will fight back! Let your guard down and a leopard will eat you. Got bored? Maybe you should go to a village and play some poker games and rob those poker players. Do you want to become Hawkeye? Legolas? or maybe Rambo? Use explosive archer and blow some goats. Got angry? Use a flamethrower and burn the forest! Far Cry 3 has many great feature for a first-person shooter. You will like it.

Far Cry 3 has cool graphics, it is one of the best graphics I've ever seen, not because its so advanced, but because the weapons first-person animation is unique, so alive and... Okay maybe it's not one of the best, but I like it. Far Cry 3 has very good performance.

Too bad Far Cry 3 multiplayer feels like it has been left out, because it's not as awesome as the singleplayer mode. I was thinking the multiplayer will be more like huge maps on the same island, hundreds of players fighting together, something like that. Same thing about the cooperative play. But at least you get to blow something up with bow in singleplayer.

Far Cry 3 is not bad, its good, I recommend this.

Rating 8/10

reviewText:
If there's one thing Far Cry 3 does incredibly well, it's give you a very detailed, open-ended game world that's loaded up with so many optional objectives, collectibles and side missions that you'll probably put the game's main narrative on hold in favor of exploring. It's a fantastic-looking first person shooter with a great combat system, and while the main story isn't exactly Shakespeare, there's enough interesting stuff going on to more than make up for it.
Far Cry 3 takes players to the tropical paradise of Rook Island, where Jason, a young 20-something vacationing in the South Pacific with his friends, is captured by a notorious pirate gang led by the violently insane Vaas. After losing his brother in an escape attempt, Jason is rescued by a man named Dennis, who brands Jason with a mysterious tattoo. Apparently, Jason has the hidden potential to become the legendary warrior that the local tribe, the Rakyat, and it's up to you to save your friends, free Rook Island from the pirates and most importantly, kill Vaas.
While Far Cry 3 may not have the same kind of gritty narrative that's chock full of grim moral ambiguity like its predecessor, Far Cry 2, the adrenaline-fueled, action-packed adventure that Far Cry 3 offers instead is still entertaining. Each story mission has a nice mix of open-ended game play and scripted sequences that can be a lot of fun to play through, but when you're crawling through ancient Chinese ruins trying to find a mythical artifact, hidden away centuries ago, or the leader of the Rakyat starts talking about how great a warrior you are, it can feel like Far Cry 3 is taking a few ideas from other popular action-adventures and trying to put a darker, edgier twist to them - and it can come across as a tad melodramatic as a result.
One of the most intriguing things about Rook Island is that it has a really complex ecosystem that feels active and alive. Throughout your travels, you'll encounter flora and fauna of all shapes and sizes, from wild boars and leopards to birds of paradise. You're just as likely to be killed by a tiger or a Komodo dragon as a gun-toting pirate or mercenary, and you'll occasionally run into skirmishes between the Rakyat and pirate forces. As you progress through the game, you'll get to see how your actions have an impact on this environment. The island starts out full of enemy-occupied outposts, and hacked radio towers make navigation difficult by shrouding large chunks of your in-game map. But as you liberate those towers and outposts, they'll reveal the surrounding area and reduce the pirates' influence in the region.
Liberating Rook Island is where Far Cry 3's impressive combat comes into play. Almost every engagement offers flexibility as to how you want to take out your opponents, and you'll build up a large arsenal of customizable weapons provided you've spent some time unlocking radio towers and looting corpses and containers for cash. Every gun, such as shotguns, silenced pistols or flamethrowers, have their own uses in a firefight, depending on if you like fast-paced battles with lots of explosions and bullets or if you prefer something that lets you be more quiet and subtle.
Far Cry 3 also introduces skill and crafting systems for improving your abilities and making equipment. Completing missions and killing enemies will grant you skill points to use on various perks that'll increase your health, damage resistance or allow you to pull off nifty action hero moves, like being able to fire a gun while riding down a zipline or using an enemy as an impromptu human shield as you gun down his buddies with his own sidearm. The crafting system is oriented around making items to support you in your adventure. Most of the island's animals can be killed and skinned to give you the materials to craft larger grenade or ammo pouches, and you'll also forage for plants to make syringes that either heal you or give temporary bonuses, like detecting enemies or animals through walls.
Far Cry 3 does have a few minor issues that could've used a bit more polish. Navigating the myriad of menus can be a pain for one, and occasionally the context-sensitive HUD has issues distinguishing whether you want to pick up a weapon or loot a corpse. Also, whatever behind the scenes mechanic controlling the random placement of NPCs can seem overeager to spawn enemies for you to encounter, leading to weird instances where you drive along an empty stretch of road only to watch as a truck-full of pirates materializes behind you. Thankfully, that happens so rarely that's it's more of a minor annoyance than anything else, but it can break the immersion slightly when it does.
If you need a break from the already content-heavy single player portion of the game, Far Cry 3 also has a robust multiplayer component with a Call of Duty-style style leveling system that'll unlock new weapons, equipment, and ally-boosting abilities as you play. Far Cry 3 also comes with a four player co-op mode, where you and a handful of friends can play through a side-narrative of four people seeking vengeance against a cruise liner captain that tried to sell them out to pirates.
Far Cry 3's single player story may have its ups and downs, but it's still an incredibly in-depth action experience. Its combat and open-ended gameplay is engaging and well-designed, and there are plenty of incentives to explore the game world to see what you can find. The multiplayer modes, while not as detailed, are a nice extra feature that's just as enjoyable as the single player campaign.

reviewText:
Far Cry 3 is a blast! Immersive landscape and environments, living wilderness, lots of enemies and multiple possibilities to take them down. Will you raid a camp Rambo-style, gun-blazing everything and everyone? Will you put C4 bombs on your car and use it to make a diversion? Will you open a cage to release a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• tiger on your enemies? Or will you sneak your way through? The choice is all yours.

The story is simple but feels alright, the characters are all pretty charismatic and have their own personalities; the game has humour and dramatic moments. It is beautiful and immersive. The gameplay is varied enough, and when you think it might become boring, new gameplay elements come in. Lots of missions and side-missions to keep you occupied for quite some time; I've played more than 16 hours when I'm writing this review and haven't even finished it yet. Take your time, do some missions, get lost in the jungle, plan your tactics and stop being a prey: be the predator.
I only wish the stealth approaches would be more realistic like it was in Far Cry 2, and a better crafting system.

At first I didn't think I'd like this game, but now I love it.

A solid 8.5 or 9/10 for this piece of work.

reviewText:
Within the first thirty minutes I experienced an incredibly emotional and engaging introduction that rivaled all my favorite memories from similar games. Remember the beginning to Half Life 2 or dying in the beginning of Call of Duty: Modern Warfare? Far Cry 3 wipes those experiences under the table and then continues to give you things you never thought possible in a game of this magnitude.  Every drug-laden sequence early in the game makes you feel like first-person shooters have risen to a new level in terms of creative narrative story-telling.

We are presented with a very typical open-world game. We can explore the scenic island, take on a slurry of optional missions, search for a staggering amount of collectibles, or take on the newest gaming cliche: hunting. The exploration feels very reminiscent of Skyrim. The stealth elements are familiar for fans of those genres. There are role playing elements and skill tree upgrades. It‚Äôs got a little bit of everything and at first-glance they‚Äôre all done well.

Even with a new high-end PC I couldn‚Äôt play this game on ultra, but on high Far Cry 3 looks absolutely incredible. Environments are gorgeously rendered allowing the player to immerse in every detail of the beaches and jungle down to single blades of grass. The character models are perfectly motion captured and so well acted that you want to know ‚ÄúWho is this guy playing Vaas?‚Äù These elements provide a real emotional connection to what‚Äôs happening. From the very start you become completely immersed and invested in your motives, the story, the characters, and the world as a whole.

So what‚Äôs the problem? Far Cry 3 is a great game that suffers from the trappings of what makes it a game. The strengths and impact of the opening sequence are quickly diminished when your first few mandatory missions act as tutorials of collecting plants and skinning pigs. With further progression you are inundated with endless optional missions, while entertaining, are irrelevant to the larger story. More may not always be better. And the more you play, you‚Äôll realize: this game is riddled with all the tropes of similar experiences.

You‚Äôll need to escape from a burning building, hunker down for turret sequences, use ‚Äústealth‚Äù to follow a person in broad daylight, and deal with a car chase where you blow up pursuers with a grenade launcher. Meanwhile, every meandering story mission you go on seems to further remove you from any logical character development. Fighting a giant tribal ink demon in a drug-induced state looks cool, but it‚Äôs completely pointless and punctuated by a ridiculous first-person sex scene. There are multiple times in the game that make you question what you‚Äôre doing and why, because at a certain point none of it makes sense.

This game would have benefited immensely from a shorter and focused campaign. What should have been a linear and powerful storyline is ruined by padding the game out with irrelevant mechanics and tired plot sequences. There was such amazing potential dealing with concepts of human trafficking and how revenge at any cost can transform an ordinary person.  However, the human drama takes a backseat. We‚Äôre left with a game that feels manipulated to meet bullet-points on a marketing checklist and a feeling that we are the lowest common denominator for a target demographic.

A lot can be learned from games like Spec Ops: The Line. What seemed like a formulaic shooter was actually a concise narrative that took risks. It explored and engaged the player with what trauma and death can do to the human psyche.

Far Cry 3 could have easily cut characters like Willis, Citra and Hoyt and focused on the drama with Vaas. The optional missions could have been made available as a narrative hook after the main campaign or online experiences with friends. The problem I have is that mechanically the game is still fun. I can recommend it for those reasons. However, narratively speaking, it had so much potential and in the end I was just disappointed with the entire package.

Far Cry 3, a story driven first person shooter.

I purchased the Deluxe edition of the game when it was on the summer 2014 sale for $9.99 and have played a total of 7 hours as of this writing.

I would fit this game into the FPS genre and add that this is more then just an FPS, its a Story Driven FPS. There is a compelling and interesting story to go through with the solo campaign of the game and the game starts off with an intense beginning.

My first several hours into the game and I have to wounder why I didn't get into the Far Cry series before. Far Cry 3 is the first game in the series I have played and I am pleased with it thus far. I do want to keep playing more and finish the story line to see how it all comes to conclusion.

There is more to the game if you play a multiplayer coop campaign but I have not yet tried that as I want to experience it all at my pace and not run and gun through it all. I will eventually play coop but not for a while.

There is lots to do in the game other then the main missions. I have spent time hunting down animals for there skins, collecting plants and exploring sunken ships, caves and ruins.

The crafting in the game is simple, its not overly complex like other games with crafting. If you want to upgrade your wallet to hold more money then you will need to collect animal skins of a certain animal. You will see what kind of animal skin is needed when you select the upgraded version and then on the map you will see the symbol of the animal. In that area somewhere you will find it, kill it and skin it. This will be how you will go about hunting animals to get there skins so you can upgrade your various gear, like, Loot sack, ammo pouch, weapon holster and so forth.

When gathering plants (Green, Blue, Read, White) you will use them to make syringes for restoring health or to make a boost in abilities. I have only made health restorative ones as of yet.

There is allot more to the game beyond the main missions. There are random supply drop's side missions where you will drive a vehicle from point to point (a marked flare on the ground) till you get the supplies to the needed person. Hunting various wildlife, timed runs, finding lost relic's, letters and video memory cards.

The game map starts off with a small section visible and as you activate radio towers throughout the map more sections become visible. The areas that are not visible also do not show up on the mini-map making it more interesting to explore and find the path the to other radio towers.

Hang-gliders are also around the island to use and sale through the air to other sections. Its kind of nice to to glide in the air over the island areas and see what there is around.

Far Cry 3 is very Xbox 360 controller friendly. Button arrangements are done well and its a joy to play with the controller over keyboard and mouse.

I didn't like that I have to access the game menu to get to the crafting and would have rather seen an option of a work table or something in a safe zone (or in the game world) for doing crafting. Other then that, I have to say that this game is very impressively done and UbiSoft did an excellent job. I am looking forward to the next Far Cry game.

Having waited during the Summer Sale of 2014 for the Deluxe edition of the game to go on sale and getting it for $9.99 I have to say a resounding Yes! I am sure that subsequent sales will have the game on sale as well. Look for it during the Holiday Sale folks.

reviewText: I definitely had a pretty good ride with this game. I was introduced into this series with Far Cry 4, with this being the second game I've played in the series. I've noticed a lot of similarites between the two games, in terms of gameplay and such. Regardless, I still had a lot of fun with the game as I loved Far Cry 4, so was bound to like this one as well. Solid graphics and gameplay. I don't really have much to complain about them. You have good combat as there are various ways to go with any situation, whether stealth or head on. Lots of stuff to explore and collect, side missions to do, and more. In terms of story, it serves the setting and game well. It kept me interested and wanting more. Setting is pretty good as well, taking place on an island with lots of mountains, forests, vegatation, caves, ocean, lakes, and much more. Lots to explore on this island. To be honest, I did have some mixed feelings with the last few events at the ending of the story, but overall, was satisfied and happy with the ending I chose and how it turned out. It took me about 36 hours to get 99% completion, for those wondering. I enjoyed the music of the game as well. A fair amount of times during the game's story where I thought it choice of music was quite suited and pretty cool. Overall, there's a lot to do in this game, from hunting, to racing, to assassination missions, to liberating villages, and much more. I was left pretty happy, impressed, and satisfied with this game. Would have no problem playing this game again, as I think of it to be a really great game that I'd definitely recommend to anyone. Two thumbs up from me!

reviewText:
After completing Far Cry 3 on normal difficulty, I am now playing through once more on the hardest difficulty and am trying to complete all of the missions this time. I usually don't play through a game twice, but this game is worth it. There are so many things I like about this game, where to start...

Open World: Far Cry 3 offers a massive, beautiful open world and allows the player to choose one's pace. You can explore the island, do missions, build up skills, build up gear, and follow the story all on your own time. The world is full of goodies like treasures, relics, wildlife (useful and some dangerous), plants, missions, vehicles, and more.

Story: A very simplistic summary would be that you play as a guy who was on a nice trip with his brothers and friends, but then things go downhill and you wakeup in a cage with your brother. You must then escape and save your friends all while building new skills and learning about the island. Of course, it is a rather intricate and enticing storyline that keeps you on the edge of your seat, especially when things heat up.

Gameplay: Unlike most first person shooters, there are so many ways you can choose to play. You can do the traditional guns-a-blazin, you can be like Hitman and stealth your way through, you can be like James Bond and use your surroundings to unleash hell on your enemies, or you can do what I did which is all of the above.

Characters: I thought the characters were very well done. One of the main antagonists in the game, Vaas, is personally my favorite video game villain I have encountered. A very interesting character indeed, though I won't say more than that, you will have to play it and find out for yourself. Besides Vaas, the other characters were also very well designed.

Weapons: This game has a weapon for everyone. Pistols, SMGs, LMGs, Snipers, Assault Riffles, Flame Thrower, RPG, Grenade Launcher, Bow, Flare Gun, Explosives, etc. When your weapon holster is maxed out you can carry four weapons. They are all very well balanced, nothing is too underpowered and nothing too overpowered. Very well done.

Vehicles: A fair variety of vehicles. Everything you would expect on an island like the one in Far Cry 3. Once again, nothing is too under or overpowered when it comes to vehicles. My favorite would have to be the glider, quite unique and very fun to use.

I could go on, but I'll just add one more thing because I think it was incorporated quite well. There are a few instances throughout the game where you are giving some type of drug that sends your character on hallucinogenic, soul searching journeys. They were quite entertaining and really added to the whole storyline. This is definitely a stoner-friendly game, however I haven't smoked while playing (yet anyway), though it would be fun.

Overall I would give this a 95/100. Not a perfect game, but very captivating. I'm also not a big fan of the Uplay launcher, but my rating didn't reflect on the launcher, just the single player game.

reviewText:
The ending is enough to justify a negative review but I'll go more in depth...

It's a Taken/Pocahontas story we've heard before: bunch of bored, spoiled, rich, white kids travel to a deserted island where they get jumped by Spanish-speaking pirates and are held for ransom. One of them runs away (the player) and the story somehow turns into a heroic epic to save Pocahontas and her people. Oh, and the friends he's slowly caring less and less about. Pocahontas and her people grant him powers that they possess but can't use the way he does (or at all) because he's American and they're incompetent and he's special and blah blah blah. Golly gee whiz, I never expected ~*~certain people~*~ to be antagonists! What an original and inspiring plot twist that led to one of the best endings in storytelling history! /sarcasm over. Been there, done that. They had a lot of potential to turn the narrative into a human experience but it was squandered into an anachronistic load of bs we've all seen over and over again. Nty.

This may just be me but the constant notifications bugged me. A lot. The game doesn't stop pestering you until you check every notification even though you've been notified of the same thing a billion times before that. I know I got a relic, game. I literally just picked it up! I know I can craft a medical syringe; that's why I got the green leaves! Hell, this game notified me so much that, after the first 15 minutes, I already knew how to craft all of the basic pouches and syringes. If I needed to remember, I could just look in the menu. I don't need you constantly reminding me! You are not an alarm so stop it!

It's a simpler version of Assassin's Creed mechanics in FPS mode. Don't get me wrong, it was still entertaining and the graphics can be absolutely breathtaking but there were too many similarities. Liberating Borgia towers/outposts was pretty entertaining to go through, especially in the second half of the game. Climbing to the highest point and synchronizing/getting radio towers working and doing the Leap of Faith/ziplining down was a tedious chore. I found it more fun to attempt a Leap of Faith and send Jason Brody awkwardly stumbling down the tower to his untimely death. Stealthing"

reviewText:
What a massive game this is. Huge islands to explore with just too many sidequests. You can just run/drive/fly around and do nothing or you can; hunt animals, craft items, free settlements, find relics and other secrets, take over radio towers, do some trials and a whole lot of other activities and (side)quests. It's seemingly endless and completing the entire game will take you probably well over 50 hours. Now that's some value right there.
The graphics are just gorgeous, no matter what settings you use. You can't make this game look bad, you just can't. The animations and models are some of the best I've seen in a game. Wow. The same thing applies to the sounds and voice acting, which is brilliant and truly convincing.
While doing the story and sidequests you'll earn XP to upgrade your skills. There are 3 skilltrees in total and the way you play the game is entirely up to you. The Shark skilltree will let you upgrade your assault and healing skills, while the Heron tree will help you with your sniper skills and speed and finally, the Spider tree will let you focus on your stealth and survival skills. There's no right way to play this. There are many ways to complete an objective. And that's what makes Far Cry 3 fun, but not necessarily unique.
However, there aren't many FPS that give you this much freedom, while telling a realistic, focused, story at the same time. So I take my hat off to Ubisoft for creating this masterpiece. The commercial and critical success for this game is well deserved.
Let this be a lesson - and example - for future first person shooters. Hooray for Far Cry 3 !

reviewText:
Far Cry 3 is a great game. The island is really a living place and you can spend a good amount of time by traveling in some car or hunting some animals. By the way, this is the best game to use a bow, I really enjoyed use it during all the game, the gameplay is fantastic.

It has some great music, sound effects and voice acting but the story could be much better, but it is almost ok. You start trying to save your friends but after some point later in the game I completely forgot about them (and I feel bad for saying it, LOL), but I was having too much fun playing around in the island, going to new towers and hunting new animals between the missions... Well, what can I do?

On the other hand, Vaas is a great and unique character, unfortunatelly the others aren't that interesting as him (except one soldier in later game...), every time you encounter him is very cool (and crazy).

After all that I went to co-op, which is a very linear and short storyline, but is fun and works great. In every mission you will face some sort of competition with your friends (sniper, jet ski, rpgs, buggies, ...) and that makes it even more fun and a lot less repetitive. You should play it.

reviewText:
I tried to like this game.

I really tried.

That's not to say Far Cry 3 is a bad game. It has some very interesting features and there are a lot of improvements over the previous game (Far Cry 2), for example:

- Better stealth. Enemies can no longer spot you from miles away and snipe you with a pistol.
- No more infinite vehicle chase. If you come across an enemy patrol, you can outrun them instead of having them follow you till the end of Earth.
- More animals. Far Cry 2 had animals (Zebras!), but thtey were extremely rare.
- No more weapon deterioation. F*** the gun jamming mechanics in Far Cry 2. All it did was to force the player to visit a gun warehouse in between mission.
- Weapon customisation - horray for red-dot sights
- Stealth take down - in Far Cry 2 if you sneak up to someone and stab them in the back you will alert everyone nearby, but in Far Cry 3 you can actually perform a stealth kill with a melee weapon and even hide their body.
- Better fast travel - I can't remember how many bus rides I took during Far Cry 2.
- Crocodiles. I will never forget the first time I see an unsuspecting NPC get dragged into the river by a crocodile.

However, this game also has a lot of flaws, some I found critical, other annoying enough to put me off the game:

- You can't save during a mission. Sure you can quick save (which btw isn't mentioned in the game manual) to keep the loot you have found, but you will lose any other progress if you don't complete the mission in one sitting. Far Cry is supposed to be an open world game, so why the heck do I have to go to the menu to abandon quest if I change my mind half way through?
- Too bloody many tigers. More than once I have seen an outpost (that I am supposed to conquer) get slaughtered by some wild tiger/komodo dragon. While it's funny to watch the first time, it rapidly gets less interesting after that.
- NPCs keep repeating the same line. It's as if they only know 20 words in total.
- Immersion break. If the locals have formed a resistance group against the pirates, aside from the occansion patrols, why is is that I seem to be the only one fighting?
- Terrible health system that forces you to choose a stealthy approach. Even with a bullet proof vest, you can only last for a few seconds in a gun fight before you health is completely depleted. You pretty much have to thin the enemy out from a distance using a silenced weapon in order to survive.
- Odd graphics. This game has some very weird shading that reminds me of cell-shaded games. It is as if the developers can't make up their mind on whether to make the game look realistic or cartoonish.

I know that a lot of people will disagree with my opinion and there are a lot of positive reviews out there regarding this game. However, I feel that I have given this game a fair chance and I just cannot get around to enjoying myself playing it.

reviewText:
No. Just no.

The game is a big step-up from its predecessor and it is really good when you're free roaming the island taking out pirate camps, exploring the monotonous but beautiful landscape. And it looks pretty nice. But that's about it.

There are a lot of problems with the pacing. Half an hour in the game and I was carrying a modern french assault rifle and a silenced sniper rifle with free access to unlimited ammo if visiting the right places.
The crafting mechanics are completely contrived (why do I need tiger-skin to make bigger pouches?) and there is a lot of dissonance between gameplay and story. The protagonist lies in doubt about his actions, about killing other people while ingame recklessly slitting throats of pirates like there is no tomorrow.

The story itself is very unengaging and the characters in it are just as boring.

The supporting cast ranges from meh" (the friends) to "completely braindead and annoying" (everyone else).
The big shaman girl is just a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•
date: calling the main character "no warrior" after he single-handedly defeated a dozen pirate camps while her so-called warriors did nothing at all.\nThe half-enemy strange guy that kidnapped your best friend attacks you with a knife. And for some contrived reason your player character pulls out his knife instead of just shooting him with the MACHINEGUN IN HIS HAND. Argh.\nVaas
recommended:
the big-bad from the beginning of the game waits around corners to punch you like... fifty times. It gets old VERY fast.

Lots of setpieces don't make the slightest sense.
I have a clear shot at the big-bad-evil-guy and am carrying around a Remington sniper rifle. Can I take the shot? Nope. Because cutscene.
I escape the pirates and decide to steal a helicopter instead of just slipping into the jungle... why exactly? Oh right
hoursPlayed:
because Vaas needs to recapture the player.
I finally get the opportunity to attack Vaas' hideout and decide to kick in his front door and go in guns blazing. Alone. Not to mention the combat in this game works best if you rely on stealth and hit&run attacks. Riiiight.

This level design belongs in a Micheal-Bay-Style FPS like Call of Duty and not in something with this kind of survival-vibe.
Also the kills on the antagonists aren't even satisfying because they're just boring QTEs.

In conclusion:
If you want a free-world action game get GTA or Just Cause 2. If you want a spectacle shooter get CoD. If you want a shooter with an engaging anti-war story get Spec Ops: The Line. If you want a first-person survival game.. uhm.. Metro? Stalker?  But not this."

reviewText:
Might not be a bad game, if Uplay wasnt so brutal. The game constantly crashes. Why is this game so buggy? When I attempt to load it will get stuck in an endless loop. If I try to buy a gun, it crashes. If I try to update my skill tree, it crashes.

When the game gets going, I have a lot of fun. I love the open world aspect. I can explore what I want and go where I want. I can take out enemies stealthy with a knife or go in guns blazing. The world is beautiful and fun to explore.

Unfortunately, I found this game can get repetitive within the first island. Rather than create new challenges, it seems like take another base (with the same enemies). Yes, you can attempt to stealth it, or go full on combat, but eventually it loses its flare. Looking for relics gets boring fast. The game designers made some interesting puzzles to solve, but it feels like bad version of Tomb Raider. Relics lose novelty fast, after 60 of them, if you arn't completely bored of them, you still have another 60 more to go. Its fun to watch the world get reinhabited by the island folk, but their animations, or scripted events get boring fast. It almost seems meaningless to take a base from the enemies and where do the good villagers come from? It would be fun to find villagers hiding and occupying little outlying huts.

Am I happy that I purchased this game? ... Yes, but because it was on sale.

reviewText:
7/10 -What a trip. I enjoyed hunting animals to craft items, Looting, finding relics and completing side missions to get money to upgrade and buy weapons, stealth killing, sniping from a long distance to shoot a cage to let a tiger out of it and watch it maul everyone nearby, taking over enemy posts so I can fast travel to them, fixing towers to show the map and unlock new weapons, running people and animals over with my car, upgrading my character with xp to unlock new moves, starting things on fire and watching it spread and last but not least the story missions. You can craft plants but I ended up not crafting any except green ones which give you health because the rest of the plants you can craft are basically useless. Who wants to craft a plant to allow you to be flame retardant for 15 secs? I didn't care anyway.

Unlike plants crafting animals is useful since you can carry more weapons at a time among other things by collecting their skins. I had fun hunting these animals in the wild and checking my list of how many I needed of a certain breed to create whatever it was. However it was pointless hunting animals anymore after you craft everything unless you want to gain barely any money in doing so or just for the hell of it. Looting dead bodies got really annoying because you have to wait and see the same animation over and over again. There is no way to skip it. Another annoying problem was if their weapon is nearby you have to hover over a certain spot on their body to loot them since you use the same key press to pick up their weapon...why couldn't I just hover over their body and get the loot automatically without pressing anything and press a key if I wanted their weapon? I ended up all the time swapping my weapon accidently because of it.

There is really no death animations just ragdoll physics. Which is disappointing since I liked how in Far Cry 2 you can snipe someones leg and they start yelling in pain from it and if one of their friends is nearby they could pick them up and carry them to safety. You shoot anyone in the leg in this game they just die and fall over. The story was a let down to me. It's really a big lame excuse to kill people on an island. You go to the extremes to save your friends in any situation. I didn't like the main characters voice it was annoying and laughable at the sametime. It doesn't help that your character is a real ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• and makes very poor decisions you have to watch unfold that you don't like. The ending wasn't satisfying at all.

Don't get me wrong though I did enjoy alot of the story missions. The co-op is alright but can be frustrating due to waves of overwhelming odds and connection issues. The motion blur in this game gave me headaches and there is no way to turn it off. I am only nitpicking here but you can't blow up a car or truck by sniping it's fuel tank. You can't cut down trees. You can't blow up a building having it's walls collapse in. You can't fly a helicopter. You can't even see your own feet. It's no Crysis that's for sure but I did have fun and I spent alot of time just wrecking havoc.

reviewText:
So I don't normally review games, mostly because I don't feel the need to, but Farcry 3 is a different case.
I've played my fair share of games, RPGs, MMOs, FPS'. But none of them have ever given me the same adrenaline rush that this game offers. Now don't get me wrong I'm sure there are better games out there, but Farcry 3s enticing story (I'm about halfway through atm) and deep character progression are something to behold. (Not to mention the incredible voice acting).
This game offer many different ways to play and there are multiple ways to complete a mission. When you're not off killing pirates and blowing s##t up, you can kick back and go out hunting (surprisingly therapeutic) or play some mini games that the villagers offer. There is an unbelievable amount to be done is this game and the whole map feels like a playground, where you do things your way.
I would go into the story, but I'd get carried away and probably spoil something, so all I'll say is that Vaas is possibly my favourite villian of all time be it in a book, movie and of course game. So I'm not saying everyone will love this game, but if you like the freedom to do whatever the hell you want and also don't mind a pretty brilliant story (in my opinion) then just buy it! I nearly didn't because of all the complaints about a so called Uplay, but trust me its not that bad! A little unesscary, but once in game you forget all about it.

reviewText:
Elements from Far Cry 1 & 2 that didn't work are gone, things that did work stayed.  Skyrim with guns, Assassin's Creed with guns, Borderlands done without the campiness.

As awful as the Far Cry 1 story was, I can actually see a connection between that & 3.  Even though each game is considered a spiritual successor and has no connection to one another, I can tell 1 & 3 have a lot of similarities in story.  The difference is, 3 isn't a hackjob story with ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• voice acting.

Beautiful graphics, great gameplay, great story, memorable characters and one thing Ubisoft does great: amazing intros to their games.  This is definitely a good 20 hour playthrough, highly recommended if you like FPS with open world questing, skills to level up, hostile outposts to clear into friendly outposts, driving, flying, shooting, hunting.  Oh yeah, the hunting is actually fun, sometimes hard and actually useful.

Great game, worth the price on sale.

reviewText:
Far Cry 3 is the king of aesthetics. The jungles scattered throughout the island are overflowing with detail, wildlife, etc. The game does a great job at having you feel immersed as you try to save your friends from an unforgiving warlord, and his henchmen. The first few hours of the game are bliss. You're just killing things, and getting tatt'ed up. The game then becomes stale. You start killing the same enemies, start recieving the same missions, and you are even forced to travel halfway across the map between missions.
Then there's the protagonist. His profile indicated he is a grown man- but his voice actor makes him sound like a disney-channel sitcom teen. This shattered it for me. His expressions even made me cringe well into the game. Though he grows, the more you learn about him, the less you want to be playing as him.

In short, 6/10 , expected something more.

reviewText:
Don't buy this game. The story is terribly written in my opinion and doesnt fit at all in the far cry series. the gameplay is very repetetive, with each outpost having the same structure. it comes too predicable that even at the hardest difficulty you can easily do well at the game just using a pistol.

In the story (Both co-op and single player) it's just cliche after cliche after cliche. It happens so often that it just gets annoying and it just feels awful. You get no connection to the protagonist at all, you won't llike him, you don't even want to be him and wish he'd just jump off a cliff, break his ankles and left there for no one to be found ever. Neither do you feel connected to the world. In most games you get a sense of where you are, roads feel familiar, certain parts feel like home. In this game it is just jungle after beach after dirt road and they all just seem the same.

The story is full of spiritual nonsense that could fit in a setting centuries ago or in a different kind of world (where magic and unicorns exist), but not in the 21-st century on a tropical island where everybody has 17 guns. If you have a gun, you don't need some pretentious spiritual power to kill just another thug with a group of his guards. Honestly, the only way the game is fun is to just avoid all storyline missions, not using the map and running around blindly shooting people. Basically what Far
Cry 2 consisted of.

The co-op is kind of alright in the game. The campaign doesnt really have that much story (this doesn't really matter though, it's about shooting things with your friends). It consists of multiple chapters which can be played chronologically. It's fun to do a few times, but the problem is that all these chapters are so repetetive and contain the same things, you never get a nice surprise. The worst part is the extreme glitchiness in Co-op. Anybody has a ping over 60? Fat chance that when you respawn after everyone dies, somebody on your team will just randomly drop dead and has to wait for the next checkpoint. Or he seems to appear on top of a building, while you're standing inside it. Good luck saving him when he gets incapacitated. Furthermore it is impossible to play with 2 players, as random kicks without a visible reason happen very often. if you play it with 2, and one gets kicked, you automatically get booted because 'there aren't enough players.' Say goodbye to your progress.

All in all, get off the store page, and spend your money on a better game. But not this, don't do this to yourself.

reviewText:
So this game, has an interesting enough concept, you get to roleplay a white whiney teenager who goes for a holiday then gets captured by a much more interesting villain who has some great dialogue and presence.

It breaks down into an Ubisoft favourite, capture X area Y times with slight variances with upgrades in weapons inbetween and a forest of trouble between the areas (like the very linear and constrained Assassin's Creed).

The much more improved part of this are the great NPCs and the environment of the jungle, you will end up getting surprise attacked by a tiger, crocodile or shark rather than getting killed by any human characters since they are quite predictable and even on ultra hard mode they are easy to sneak up on.

The game has XP and money barriers for progression but there is an interesting hunting and gathering requirement which requires you to gather animal and plant products for consumables and how much ammo or how many guns and consumables  can be carried.

Littered throughout the open world are various racing and shooting mini games in addition to hunting, searching and assassinaitng quests.  This is all great and fun indeed.

The graphics are quite great especially with everything turned up.

You're probably asking why I don't recommend this game.

Ubisoft seems to have trouble programming and supporting its titles beyond console release.

Thsi game is littered with gamebreaking bugs, glitches and will make your machine regardless of if it is top of the line 2 years ago or top of the line today to crash or hang.

Sometimes you'll be able to play the game for 4 or 5 hours straight no problems other times you'll have difficulty having it running for 15 minutes.

It seems to be a theme with Ubisoft every PC port they make has an unexcusable number of problems.

In addition to this there is the extra layer of trashware implemented - Uplay.  Which is basically a massive Ubisoft advertisment which requires administrative access to run and is morethan likely one of the causes for autosave points to crash your machine.

If you would like your machine to crash more times in the one playthrough of a game than over the last 3 years, by all means buy this game.  If you want ot keep your sanity and send a message to Ubisoft that PC gamers will not put up with a half ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• job then do not buy this game.

reviewText:
Date of review: 10.24.2014

Platform: PC



Released in 2012, Far Cry 3 became a huge success, considered by many the game of the year (or at least the FPS of the year), something which I also believe it fully deserves. An open world FPS experience has never felt so polished before.

Story:

In the third installment of the Far Cry series you take over the role of Jason Brody, a 25 year old american daredevil who is currently on a holiday with his friends and brothers in Thailand. Everything is party and fun until the group goes skydiving over the supposedly uninhabited Rook Islands, only to land on a world occupied by pirates who deal with kidnapping and human trafficking‚Ä¶

While the plot is not as mature and meaningful as the one of Far Cry 2, it‚Äôs more than first meets the eye, being a carefully built satire.

Characters are very deep, and Vaas Montenegro is one of the coolest antagonists ever to show up in a game.

Though not directly related to the main plot/story line, the detailed history of Rook Islands (going back all the way to ancient China), the Rakyat (the native people of the islands) the Japanese occupation during the second world war, etc. adds a lot to the game and to the immersion.

9/10


Visuals:

Far Cry 3 looks absolutely stunning. Colorful yet wild, the tropical world has never looked so good and alive before, with breath taking landscapes and dozens of animals roaming/flying around. This is definitely one of those games you just enjoy by looking at. The variety is also impressive, from the lush jungles to the sandy beaches, from ancient temples to small villages, it‚Äôs simply a pleasure to roam around, and explore, and the small details really make it feel rewarding.

Combat also looks and thus feels great, with brutal animations and beautiful explosions, making firefights incredibly fun.

The day-night cycle (although somewhat short) is present as well and adds a lot to the visuals, creating sights which will easily take your breath away.

Of course, such visuals will require a decent system in order to run smoothly on High and/or Ultra detail settings. On the test rig (for reference see test system specifications at the bottom of the review), I could run Far Cry 3 at 1080p Ultra details and 2xMSAA with very good frame rates. I did get some rare fps drops in very intense fight scenes, but even then the game was more than smooth enough to be played. Turning MSSA over 2x however, pretty much killed my frames, but this is absolutely acceptable considering the visual quality. All in all, you will need something like an Intel Core i5 3570K or an AMD FX-8350 CPU paired with a GeForce GTX 770 (GTX 680) or an AMD Radeon R9 280X (HD 7970 Ghz Edition) GPU to be able to play on Ultra settings with 2-4xMSAA at 1080p resolution. However, I also know people who play Far Cry 3 on low end PC's or laptops and they were still able to get decent fps rates on low to medium detail settings, so the game seems to be quite well optimized... thumbs up for Ubisoft (for a more in depth analysis on system requirements I advise you to check the Far Cry 3 Performance Test: Graphics & CPU" on Techspot).

10/10


Gameplay:
