reviewText:
Singleplayer:
Campaign:
I played the campaign on it's hardest difficulty and it took me somewhere around 15 hours. The story is about Jason Brody having a vacation on an island. And wakes up in a cage realising that his vacation is over and he has to save all his friends so they can get back home. This sounds and also felt generic. But as you continue through the game the story gets more and more interesting, due to well voiced characters and the inspiring monologues. The game also felt like some kind of total recall to me, because the character has many drug trips. So even when I was playing the normal sp missions I was asking myself if it wasn't just a drug trip. Because if the bulk of the story was a drug trip the story would make a lot more sense. The campaign story was mostly the reason that kept me playing.

Gameplay:
The gameplay other hand was good and entertaining, but nothing special for me. Some early missions could be annoying, because you were forced to play stealthily. Also the sp missions can sometimes feel as a narrow route.  The power of the gameplay itself is that you can choose how you want to play. stealthily or guns blazing. Both can be fun but both also have some issues. The stealth problem is that the ai can be annoying. And for guns blazing you can easily run out of ammo and have to break your arm to revive yourself many times if you play guns blazing.(Atleast on my difficulty. I would maybe recommend to play 1 difficulty below or first do a lot of side missions to unlock more health, weapons etc.) Also if you have no ammo you mostly have to camp until you can easily knife someone, without getting hit. Sadly every endboss fight from the game showed the definition of insanity in gameplay. The game was also a bit overwhelming in the beginning because of the many menus with upgrades. At first I ignored them, but later I really saw the benefit of it. Otherwise you will easily die.  The graphics of the game still look nice, I especially liked the lighting. And how much effort there had been put into the building.

Open World:
I have to be honest I haven't done that much in it. Because I wasn't really interested in it. Still I can say if you are interested in exploring the world there is alot to do! There are enough side-missions, which is mostly killing enemies/animals in a certain way, missions where you have to go from A to B as fast as you can etc and, of course, collecting stuff. Really the only thing that made me stop fast-traveling from mission to missions was the tower climbing and the animal/flower hunt to unlock stuff. They were more rewarding to me than the side missions that just give you money and xp that I already had enough of.

Online:

Multiplayer:
In my opinion the mp isn't that special. It has 4 standard game modes. Of course they are varied with some nice ideas. But to me it just feels like a cod-clone. The multiplayer also has a strong map editor. Probably at the time there were many great mods made. (I found some interesting ones on youtube. ) But now that the game isn't as active anymore, I couldn't find a modded map to play.
-Co-op:
I played the co-op with someone many months before continuing my singleplayer campaign. It was pretty long at 6-8 hours. But still the co-op was pretty generic and forgetable. The only thing that I liked were the mini-games. What is strange is that the multiplayer and the co-op leveling system are combined. So if I had only played Co-Op, I would have all the unlocked loadouts for the multiplayer.

Overall:
I can say Farcry 3 is a great game, but you can ignore the multiplayer and co-op, because they aren't that special and that active anymore. I think for the people who only own FarCry 4, FarCry 3 is still a great game to play, especially for the campaign, that makes it something special.

reviewText:
Far Cry 3 is a hugely enjoyable open world FPS set on a beautiful tropical island.

Game-play is great, providing many alternate methods of completing your objectives. This offers players the chance to use stealth and silent weapons to pick off their enemies one-by-one while remaining undetected. Alternatively you can run in and gun everyone down, which is slightly less fun and not as rewarding. Many games boast this feature of choice and always seem to be lacking in either the stealth system or just general combat. I'm glad to say that Far Cry 3 delivers on both fronts.

The game offers a huge array of things to do aside from the main campaign. There are around 30 outposts, 20 radio towers and tons of extra side missions sprawled around the game map. Completing all of these side activites is bound to give you numerous benefits, but not without a challenge. Far Cry 3 also contains one of the best hunting system I've seen in gaming. While not forcing you to have to hunt for survival or anything, hunting will give you many materials to help craft items to make you character carry more items, weapons and money.

Now, the story. At first the story of Far Cry 3 doesn't seem like much, you're an American tourist on holiday with your friends to an exotic Indonesian island. But what lives on this island is much more sinister than you expect. A huge group of pirates, lead by Vaas Montenegro, a once good man driven to insanity by the temptations of evil.

You are Jason Brody, a typical American who has a desire for adventure. The character arch of Brody is great, showing how much a man can change when something is taken from him. The story is one of madness, strength and discovering the darkness of human nature.

The visuals are pretty excellent. The world is colourful, vibrant and perfectly lit, the island and all of the characters on it look spectacular, even on the medium settings my PC was forced to run it at.

The soundtrack is overall pretty great, especially a track which appears toward the end of the main campaign.

I highly recommend picking this up if you're a fan of FPSs and/or open-world games. It's worth it at full price but this game is no stranger to sales so it might be best to wait until the time is right and pick it up for less.

uPlay also seems to be bearable with this.

reviewText:
Quite a memorable game with memorable characters. Despite being mostly a free-roam game, with plenty of distractions and activities, like hunting, killing, swimming, gliding etc. it has a decent story.

As I mentioned in the beginning, the characters are one of the strongest points in this game, every character with their own strong personalities, each one with their own insanity, great voice acting and motion track. The motivation and choice freedom of the protagonist feel a bit wooden and not quite dynamic, but the diversity in the activities, making it feel not quite so linearity dependent, compensates for the lack of story control.

The story can be easily completed with minimum of effort, since difficulty doesn't really represent an impediment (if you play shooters often, you can aim for the highest difficulties), but making the side activities do help in certain cases, especially for the traveling part.

The vehicle control is quite fluent, reminds me of the car from Half-Life 2. The weapons can be customized in a variety of ways, from adding attachments to adding a camo, quite easy to use, they have ironsight, so for any Call of Duty player they should be a no-brainer.

It has a sort of RPG-like skill tree, which allows you to get new abilities and features, supporting your gameplay as well as your herb/animal crafting system.

The co-op is average, not much of a story, really linear levels, it's basically a cooperative competition, since each level contains a sort of mini-game with ranking, so you will be able to beat your friends and brag about it. It's sometimes bugged, you may be spawning dead, fall through the ground.

The multiplayer is quite...empty...not many people play it, it has basic game modes like team deathmatch and domination like modes, feels a lot like a Call of Duty" style. You also have a multiplayer leveling system (not the same with the one from single player)

reviewText:
Far Cry 3 is a game that takes place in Rook Island, which is divided into North Island and South Island. You begin the game as Jason Brody, an American tourist who is vacationing with his friends looking for fun on this tropical paradise. Things go wrong when pirates kidnap them for the purpose of selling them into slavery. You encounter a leader named Vaas Montenegro, who makes life a living hell for you and your friends. Later you‚Äôll run into another nasty guy in the name of Hoyt Volker, who lives in the South Island has more powerful pirates protecting him.
Jason may seem like an ordinary guy, but you can make him quite powerful using the skill tree system. There is plenty to explore, including the plant life, the animal life, and the numerous outposts controlled by the pirates. You will also get to know the Rakyat, the natives of the island and you will learn their traditions as you progress through the story. The story missions are interesting and well-scripted, but the most exciting part of the game is being able to freely explore the island when not working on a story mission. The world has plenty of randomness such as shootouts between the Rakyat and the pirates. Other times you will see animals attacking the Rakyat. On some occasions you will see animals like bears, tigers, and leopards attacking the Rakyat tribe. On other occasions you will see tigers or bears stalking boars. Sometimes the predatory animals will come after you and you will have to kill them in order to survive. Other times you see a pack of dogs with one howling like a wolf. You look around to see if these animals are stalking you.
There can be benefits to killing animals in the game. After killing them you can skin them in order to craft bigger wallets to hold more cash and craft loot rucksacks to carry more leaves and loot recovered from containers and dead bodies. Liberating outposts requires you to kill all pirates guarding them so that they can be your safehouse. The game rewards you more for using stealth than for going all out on a shootout against the pirates. Each outpost contains alarm panels near the flags representing the outposts that pirates can use to call reinforcements should they find you. But you can shoot out the alarm panels to eliminate the possibility of reinforcements. The sniper rifle comes in very handy when trying to liberate outposts. I would shoot a few pirates and find a place to hide by hiding behind rocks and in the foliage. The XP gained from liberating outposts is used to develop Jason in different ways. This is the RPG element of Far Cry 3. There really no wrong skill to learn because all the skills are useful in some way. You can learn to take down an enemy from behind using the brutally effective machete. Then you can learn to take down an enemy by taking one down from behind and throwing the machete immediately to take down a nearby enemy without alerting others. Liberated outposts offer side missions such as assassinations and hunting animals both common and rare. You have to complete assassinations by using your brutal knife, so using any other weapon will result in mission failure. This is in line with Rakyat tradition that you will learn to respect in Rook Island. The hunting of animals requires you to first stop by a site to pick up a weapon designated for hunting the animals. Using any other weapon will result in mission failure. The hunting of rare animals is rather interesting because the skinning of these animals will help you craft larger wallets, larger ammo pouches, larger loot rucksacks, larger syringe kits, etc. So hunting and crafting go hand in hand and will help you throughout your exploration of the island.
Whether you‚Äôre hunting, crafting, searching for relics or lost letters from dead WWII Japanese soldiers or progressing through the main story, Far Cry 3 is rarely boring. You can unscramble radio towers throughout the island to make your map clearer to read and to help Rakyat supply lines. As soon as you kill deactivate a radio tower, you will have a supply drop side mission available. Supply drops require you to drop medical supplies within a certain time limit. This type of side mission lets you know how treacherous driving can be in Rook Island. It also can get a little repetitive. In my opinion, the supply drops side missions are the most tedious in the game.
There are many vehicles that you can drive, but driving on the roads can feel a bit awkward. Driving boats and watercraft can be a lot of fun while exploring the gameworld by sea. You can navigate from one place to another by ziplining, which is more fun from a first-person view than I expected. It‚Äôs cool to zipline, get to drop down on a pirate, and brutally stab him at the same time. There are hang gliders scattered throughout the island that you can use to reach faraway places or hard to reach areas.
In the original Far Cry you could use binoculars to tag enemies you see in the distance. Far Cry 2 removed that feature to make it more realistic. Far Cry 3 has brought back the ability to tag enemies in the distance, so you will be able to see enemies through walls after tagging them. Weapons would eventually wear down in Far Cry 2, so you had to replace them. In Far Cry 3 weapons never wear down from use and you can upgrade them using the built-in store in each safehouse for a price. Some weapons can be upgraded by using attachments such as a sniper scope, a laser sight, or a silencer. Some weapons can also be customized by painting them in a variety of colors that are available in the built-in store.
The AI in the game is very good, as you will see enemies react to dead bodies. They will automatically go into search mode in an attempt to find you. They will try to flank you if they detect you or they can hide behind objects such as rocks and shacks. They enemies work as a team when trying to find you and kill you.
The graphics of Far Cry 3 have very impressive textures and make Rook Island look alive. The animals are incredibly detailed and so are the skies whether it‚Äôs sunny or raining. The details of the faces of the Vaas and Hoyt look amazingly realistic as do the faces of the pirates.
Without trying to spoil the end of the game, I will only say that there are two endings. Each ending leaves you with moral choices to contemplate. The story missions are somewhat linear, but having two possible endings for the game makes it more entertaining.
In my opinion, Far Cry 3 is the best in the Far Cry series. The other two Far Cry games emphasized an open gameworld, but Far Cry 3 is the most open gameworld and the random encounters really help this game. The randomness ensures that the result of approaching an outpost will never be the same each time. You may infiltrate an outpost on your own only to be interrupted by a predatory animal such as a bear, tiger, or leopard. Sometimes, your attempt to liberate an outpost is thwarted by a jeep filled with pirates. Far Cry 3 is a classic action game that I highly recommend to anyone.

reviewText:
Let's start by talking about why Assassin's Creed 3 is pish. It's a game obsessed with making you play exactly how the designers had intended. Those rewards you get for full synchronisation aren't rewards for playing well; in fact, withholding them is a punishment for playing a mission any way the designers didn't intend. Assassin's Creed 3 wants you to hit certain beats to look stylish and will end the game if you don't dance to its tune.


Back in Assassin's Creed 2 the series valued emergence - the kind of crazy nonsense that might or might not happen depending on how you did or didn't play. You'd get a target and more often than not you'd do your thing and the game was happy for you to do it the way you want. Far Cry 3 loves emergence, and that makes it a more authentic Assassin's Creed than Assassin's Creed 3.

It's not an unfair comparison. They were mostly developed at the same studio in Montreal, they both begin with the same old quote from Alice in Wonderland and then they both proceed to share the same ideas all over the place - similar towers to climb, similar minigames to play, a similar focus on hunting endangered critters, and a similar structure - with one critical difference: Far Cry 3 lets you do most things your way. It's a thirty-hour anecdote generator and some of the year's best gaming moments have been emergent madness spawned by Far Cry 3's checkpoint assaults.

Now, there's a lot I dislike about Far Cry 3. The campaign has all your Game Design Favourites like Forced Stealth, Escort Missions, and First Person Platforming is terrible. I don't want to have to keep leaving the game to see my map or craft items and I don't see why Far Cry 2's magical cardboard in-game map couldn't have carried over to Far Cry 3.

I once grumbled about Far Cry 2's respawning checkpoints but 3's alternative has you gradually stripping the world of content until there's nothing left to fight but a bunch of tapirs. And I'm not keen on the - to lapse into sociology-speak - othering" of the Rakyat

reviewText: Okay, I'd give this game a 6/10.  The open-world gameplay and combat is solid and it's what I enjoyed the most.  That said, there's no other reason to pick up FC3.  The story is very weak.  The writer has defended it by saying it's a parody.  Just because it's a parody or a commentary does not mean weak writing is excusable.  If anything, a good parody is harder to write.  And it shows.  The story is weak, the character development is predictable or non-existent for anyone other than the protagonist and the endings are lackluster.  This is not a deep game, it is not a well-written game, and it is not a game you should play for the story.  However, if you enjoy killing pirates and open-world exploration and combat that is toned down from TES level, you'll have some fun.  Just don't expect it to get any better than that, it certainly won't blow your mind.

reviewText: I wish I could recommend this game. It's moderately fun for the majority of it - aside from the annoying dream sequences - but the main story ground to a halt when I was suddenly forced to go on a stealth mission that automatically fails if you're ever detected. The fact that this restriction had not previously existed in any mission beforehand coupled with an imperfect AI detection screen (they saw me through a solid door once) and it made for an impasse in the game and - ultimately - left me unable to recommend this game.\n\nIn an era of games like Dishonored, artificial stealth requirements - especially when I'm carrying more than enough ammunition to kill everyone in the base - just ruin the gameplay. There are too many other games that don't suddenly manufacture artificial requirements in missions to play to waste time on this one.

reviewText: Far Cry 3 seems promising, at first.  I think.  To be honest, no.  There was always a glimmer of this being Just Cause 2 meets Tomb Raider reboot meets maybe a dash of Spec Ops crazy, but it takes these good ingredients and pops out a mediocre product.   It's also full of rather game-ruining bugs, which were promised to be patched up by Uplay and Steam but ultimately cut many hours of progress to shreds (the camera/rocks could not be accessed, all my guns and ammo were stripped for no reason at all.)\n\nMaybe it's better on consoles, but it's ultimately a very, very generic product (Hope you like recapturing the same little outpost 32 times) outdone by its predecessors and JC2.

Words literally how amazingly amazing it felt to play this game. The story mode was well thought out and executed perfectly, an original story with everything else was amazing. I do not wish to spoil the story too much because you NEED to play this game. Basically you are a tourist visiting an island when suddenly something goes wrong‚Ä¶

‚Äì The graphics 10/10
Graphic-wise the game is beautiful and detailed, when you‚Äôre playing it, it feels like skyrim but with better graphics and more realistic weapons. Sure some computers may not be able to run the game, but the majority of the people who can run the game on the best graphics will admit it you can feel a simple breeze from the wind. The weather system can‚Äôt be talked bad about at all because the rain wasn‚Äôt too annoying, but was made just perfect.

‚Äì The A.I 8/10
The A.I is the only element in the game I could complain about, yet it was marvelous. In times during the game I noticed some A.I glitching in the wall or just auto-noticing me behind a wall. In other times the A.I were just surprisingly professional by avoiding all walls and hiding behind baricades while shooting me only when I stand up to shoot them! Also the A.I of animals was made so they act like they do in real life, from turtles crouching in their shell to sharks slowly getting closer and going in for the kill.

‚Äì The Controls 10/10
Everything was designed wisely, starting from the basic-in-every-game controls like WASD and Shift to sprint to smaller details like switching items in your inventory around the way you like.

‚Äì The gameplay 10/10
This is the main element of the game which is most essential. The possibilities are infinite, you can play the game as vanilla as you want by using weapons you pick up from the enemy but you can‚Äôt taste the game truly unless you‚Äôve tried the RPG‚Äôs or the Flamethrower. The leveling up system in the game is not like any other but a very original concept. You unlock new weapons and get them free in shops by claiming land from the enemy or climbing radio towers which noticeably become harder to get on top of with every new one. You can also convert to be a better warrior for the sake of the island by leveling up and getting ‚ÄúTatau‚Äù aka Tattoo‚Äôs on your arm which give you abilities like holding your breath underwater longer or decreasing the damage you take from animal bites.

‚Äì The Ending 10/10
I really can‚Äôt talk much about the ending to not spoil it, but the way you want the game to end is all up to you. There are 2 endings so it‚Äôs all up to you how you end the game.
‚Äì Final Verdict 10/10
The Game as a whole is a 10/10. A First person survival which has more then 30+ Realistic animals. I recommend everyone to play it.

reviewText:
Far Cry 3 is like your favourite action movie. It has snipers, exploding vehicles, and a maniacal villain named Vaas. Already this may sound like a clich√©d shooter, but Far Cry 3 does so many things well, that it‚Äôs hard not to dive back into its world again.

Along your perilous journey, you will climb up a radio tower, cover yourself in magical tattoos, and drive a quad-bike into a river. All of these elements, while definitely daredevilish, don‚Äôt feel out of place in Far Cry 3. The map is vast, and allows you to explore to your heart‚Äôs content. Hunt wild animals to collect their skin, or liberate enemy outposts to gain respect amongst the civilians. In Far Cry 3, it‚Äôs completely up to your how you approach situations.

Beneath the crazy guise that Ubisoft paints with Far Cry 3, lies a character that actually cares. Jason Brody, along with his other twentysomething friends, travel to the remote Rook Islands, for a holiday. But all is not what it seems. Vaas, a psychopathic leader of Rook Island, captures Jason and his friends. Jason escapes, but his other friends are not with him. Jason must meet with local islanders to find his friends and go home. Playing Far Cry 3, I thought Jason was an excellent character with a determined, hard-working spirit, who wants nothing but to keep his friends safe.

Vaas is a wonderful villain, with humour, but also a sort of finess on how he handles situations. The strange calmness he portrays is intimidating, but at the same time, left me uneasy. He is definitely a unique character, and one that I welcomed into the game. The only this is, Vaas seemed to swear a lot, often too much. This took away from his character slightly, and was one of the only disappointments I had with this game.

Far Cry 3‚Äôs gameplay is diverse, entertaining and never gets old. One moment, you will be fighting for your life setting pirates on fire, and the next you will be jumping out of a plane in a wingsuit. All of these never felt nuanced or out of place, and whether you are using a keyboard and mouse or a controller, the controls are easy to pick up, and similar to other games of its genre.

The game‚Äôs campaign mode is quite long, and lasted me around twelve to fourteen hours. While it is definitely the main aspect of Far Cry 3, after you finish your missions on Rook Island, there are still so many other places to explore and new things to discover. Loot is found everywhere throughout the vast map, hidden in crates. Bodies can also contain money and trinkets, which can be sold for money at stores. Plants are also found on the minimap, each a different colour. I found the Green Leaves especially useful for crafting important medical syringe kits, which have saved me from death countless times.

The customization of weapons in Far Cry 3 is amazing. If you really want to, you can add a Red Dot Sight to a .44 Magnum handgun, or an extended magazine to an ACE assault rifle. All of these can also be customized with decals and camos, letting you find the weapons that are more suited to your play style. You can equip an M249 SAW, an LMG, and a LPO-50 Flamethrower and torch the lot, or go in silently with a silenced Z93 and a Recurve Bow with a Reflex Sight. In Far Cry 3, it‚Äôs completely your choice.

Vehicles in Far Cry 3 could have been much improved. There were only three ‚Äúclasses‚Äù of vehicles, like the army-like 4WDs or the sedans and quad bikes. These all handle basically the same, and I personally am not a fan of first-person driving and was disappointed you couldn‚Äôt change this. Also, vehicles are scarce around Rook Island, and I was often without a ride and sprinting for ages to get to a destination in time.

Overall, Far Cry 3 is an amazingly diverse, creative and humongous first-person adventure, and one that will keep you glued to your monitor in excitement and anticipation as it shows you a fantastically good time.

reviewText:
Far Cry 3, a game designed by Ubisoft! We're talking about an Action - First Person Shooter game! Well, it is well known for its Single Player mode, which I have to admit that I've found extremely well designed and of course, vicious! Also, we have to mention at this point that Far Cry 3 is an open world game, which gives you even more options concerning the gameplay (Herb Gathering, Animal Hunting etc.). The storyline is the following: You (Jason Brody) are on vacation with your brother and your friends in an awesome, abandoned, tropical island. You are trapped by some criminals who are led by Vaas and Hoyt, two evil and reckless masterminds. While you and your brother are kept under captivity you finally succeed to escape the enemy camp and then... Your adventure begins with one simple goal to achieve: find and rescue the rest of your friends!Will you succeed? It all depends on you and your judgement! Go and find it out! The game, simply amazed me (as I expected it to) and I was left fully satisfied by it. As for its multiplayer, it's fine and pretty simple (If you have played Battlefield/Call of Duty you will get what I'm talking about)! I didn't find anything exciting about it, but I have to admit that I really had fun playing it. Give it a try if you want to, but definitely complete the Single Player first! In conclusion I want to mention that there are various side-missions that are worth your time (I've finished all of them and I do strongly recommend you to do the same) Also I find that the game's characterization was simply breathtaking! They did a fine job with the game's design in general.

reviewText:
Far Cry 3 is a sum of many ubisoft games, they have taken many features from their other IPs and successfully combined it with the tropical setting of far cry 1 the end result is a brilliant open world fps that is exciting to play till the end.

There is coop and competetive multiplayer in FC3, the PvP is decent fun you level up fairly quickly and have battle cries and can customize a lot, you can spend a decent amount of hours in it before getting bored, the PvE is really fleshed out and the characters are well written and is objective based you will have better luck finding a game in the competitive mp rather than the coop mp.

The single player is a very diverse,really fleshed out levels and thoroughly exciting until the end. The best part i loved about FC3 was that it rewarded stealth play example if you take out an outpost you get 500 xp take out the outpost but without triggering the alarm and you get 550 xp and if you take out the outpost without being detected you get 1500 xp. This is the reason why i almost always used stealth to take out outposts and you can do the same in most of the missions. The wildlife makes it feel like a real world where you can skin animals and sell it for cash or use for crafting, the herbivores will run away scared of you the carnivores will actively attack you and try to kill you, you can also set animals like bears,tigers and lions on the enemies by luring the animal to them or by shooting the caged animals which is a lot of fun.

Traversing through FC3 is a blast you can use the outposts you captured as fast travel, the cars are decent to use the water vehicles are very fun to use espically the jetski, the most fun you can have traveling is when you ziplines and the glider, later during the late game you will have access to wingsuit and paracute which makes traveling from one point to the other even more exhillariting and fun to do. FC3 is a looker it looks really good and the vistas change from region to region some of the segments are breathtaking, the level of detail if you can run it on very high/ultra is mindblowing, the lighting the shadows and the particle effects are really well done, the facial animation doesnt look that well but it is a 4 year old game now so cant complain too much. The jungle truly comes alive as the meshes of the trees grass and plants make it feel really life-like.

I feel FC3's villian characters are really interesting with backstories and are well developed especially Vaas whose voice actor really brings the character to life but the hero characters espcially the main hero J.Brody is not intersting nor convincing the character will blurt out stupid puns and make fun or everything and sometimes acts all serious making him feel like a man-child. The story is simple and the game has two endings, i only wish they made the bad" ending somewhat better but i guess then it wouldnt be the bad ending but overall the story is servicable and the characters for the most part are good.

There is a lot to do in FC3 from unlocking towers to view segments of the maps

Well just completed it....aaaand well I dont think its nearly as good as people make it out to be.
The main story is imo extremely short, and too much out of your hands.
In the end you get a choice, but honestly it barely is a choice from the perspective of the player, we only kinda know about our main characters background but what we play and thus experience is the complete other side of the coin.
So this choice in the end is some stuff we get told apperently happened....vs the stuff we ACTUALLY experienced in the game....so yeah, not much of a choice really.

And what is with the Hype around Vaas?
Dude is seriously barely in teh game, hell everyone is barely there because the core story is so damn short but man, Vaas is in like what, 3 scenes?
Whoop di ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•, and nothing about those were remarkable or memorable, hardly the Bane from Dark Knight Rises now is he?

Story falls apart in many places anyway, like the bs reason as to why I cannot instandly kill main baddy, ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• was also so damn predictable urhhhggggg.

The Island is huge and the game looks good and places are recognisable, soon you will know you way around just like you do after playing a while of GTA, thats all pretty cool.

reviewText:
Far Cry 3 is an interesting return to form for Ubisoft.

What is it? Well it's adventure to put it bluntly, and it seems like they geared the whole game around it. Adventure, action, survival. It's plot bares very interesting similarities to 19th century adventure stories like Treasure Island, with the protagonist having to face pirates and psychologically grow stronger as a character.

In terms of gameplay the game is fundamentally very similar to Far Cry 2, but at the same time very different. The plot structure is more cinematic and focused on story. Adding to that, animals are much more heavily focused upon. The game introduces a crafting system and inorder to carry more guns and ammunition you must skin specific animals. This actually makes the game very interesting with how you hunt animals in the overworld and breaks up the monotony of killing pirates fairly effectively.

That's not to say the game is without flaws. While the protagonist is portrayed as an everyman, even on the hardest difficulty you are death incarnate outside of cutscenes. Adding to that the game's sidequests are more or less just Kill this particular enemy with a specific weapon" or "find this particular animal".

Ubisoft designed the world very effectively. Overall it's kill pirates

reviewText:
When are words not enough to describe how amazing a game is? When you experience something so great, so beautifully crafted, with so much attention to detail that you find it hard to find a word, or words that perfectly reflect what you have just experienced. With Far Cry 3, I find myself in a state of awe, struggling to best define this masterpiece.

Far Cry 3 is in all sense of the word, remarkable. It has an amazing story, a beautifull location to explore, tons of missions, side quests and activities to do, and even racing. Although some of the aforementioned activities are optional, you will feel like the game experience won't be complete unless you engage in them, and they are quite rewarding and most importantly, a whole lot of fun.

You play as Jason Brody, a regular guy on vacation with two of his brothers, his girlfriend and some friends. The vacation however quickly turns into a nightmare, forcing Jason to do things he never thought possible, gathering strenght and courage with the help of a local tribe, the Rakyat in order to free your friends and liberate the island from drug dealing pirates, and a human trafficking organization.

Rook Island, where the game takes place is not only beautifull, it is also a very dangerous place. From pirates to privateers, to the local fauna, this place feels alive to the point of making you getting lost in it. You are not playing a game, you are fighting for survival. The animals in the game act realistically, and attack you, and can greatly affect the outcome of battles versus your enemies as well. You will need to hunt some of these beasts to craft inventory items, which will let you carry more weapons and ammo for example. Expect to find Bears, Tigers, Komodo dragons and even crocodiles on your journey. Flora also has an important role. You can craft syringes to aid you on your quests, and in order to do so you need to gather plants of several kinds, allowing you to create some really helpfull items. It is very believable and incredibly realistic, in this aspect I have never encountered a game that makes you feel that what you are experiencing on screen could easily be a real life situation.

It is a violent game, gritty at times, and that contributes a lot to the feeling and believability throughout the experience. Characters will swear and have no problem in handling situations in the most violent of ways possible. Unlike Far Cry 2, the characters in this game are memorable, which makes you care about what happens to them in the game. Be warned that this game messes with your sense of morality, some choices you will need to make will leave you in shock.

This game requires Uplay, and some people have a problem with it, for whatever reason. In my experience I have had no problem with it, and even though it shouldn't be necessary to play it, it is not a hassle to deal with. If you are not playing this masterpiece because of this, and you are a steam user, it is utterly hypocritical of you since Uplay is the same kind of DRM as Steam is. Don't let Uplay stop you from experiencing one of the best games ever made, and in my opinion, the best sandbox FPS ever created.

Far Cry 3 is brilliant, amazingly crafted and expertly executed.

The good

-Beautifull graphics and music
-Huge variety of weapons
-Memorable locations to explore and characters to interact with
-Strong, believable story
-Co-Op
-Enemy AI
-Skill Trees, RPG style, that allow you to create a character to suit your playing style

The Bad

-Nothing I encoutered could be classified as bad, but if I want to be nitpicky, some animations could have been a litlle bit better

10/10 Masterpiece

reviewText: Far Cry 3 was an interesting experience. The core game mechanics were very fun and responsive but the problem of the game turned out to be the story. The game went the usual GTA sandbox route where you can just roam the game world doing various activities or engage in the story missions. Those story missions just weren‚Äôt very fun. The thing is that instead of building over the existing fun gameplay they seemed to constantly take away from it by constraining the ways the player could play the missions and filling them with quick time events. To top it all off the characters and script of the game were just ridiculously clich√©d and uninspired outside of barely few fun exceptions. Even the missions themselves quickly boiled down to just following markers and watching cutscenes. The main character in particular was just not convincing at all and made me question if anyone in Ubisoft knew anything about human beings. As I said the core game mechanics were very good (if you don‚Äôt count the driving sections) and at best made me think of games like Fallout 3 and Just Cause 2. Lastly, I need to point out that people making Far Cry games seem to have an endless fascination with tropics and paradise islands. I happen to hate them. Here‚Äôs for hoping that the next Far Cry game will take place in some sort of Twin Peaks inspired setting.

reviewText: Pirates, mercenaries, tigers, komodo ankle-‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•s, sharks, crazy birds and heavily armoured opponents, there is not enough adjectives to discribe the joy that can be had on these islands. Hang-gliding, stealing cars, sniping from heaven's dunny window - this game covers a lot of great adventure, so well presented and thought out there may be hope for game development after all. Some missions are a bit daft but exhibiting a good strategic approach give highly rewarding First Person Shooter gameplay and the island is a dream of a battlefield. The plot line and characters show signs of cliche but that pales under a more holistic overview. The locals are friendly and almost totally hapless but good natured and honest; you don't see that handled well much The good missions and the activities that ramp skills give one a sense of mastery and a progression akin to a greek fable involving smiting enemies and semi-clad wymmyn with big boobies. Sure, your brother was shot in the head and your friends get taken hostage but the ability to take your ugly revenge seems all the more sweet.... Hmmm... It is a fantasy, after all. Lots of work is obviously gone into this adventure island full of madmen with molotovs, corrupt driven psychopaths and sneaking RPG goons.\nThe co-op multiplayer is a treat if you can navigate the almost useless game joining system. A side story to rival the main (SP) plot with plenty of challenge and explosions. The inclusion of a mini-game to ease the inner beast is a cool idea and well handled. The Directing algorythm cheats like f*ck but the play is engrossingly fun. Multi player can get a little hectic but there are many modes worthy of trying. Come to Rook Island and have a great holiday from mediocrity - who knows? you just might stay after all.\n9.7

reviewText:
Far Cry 3 is a good game, a great game even. You could even say it's an excellent game. No game is without fault however I'll talk about some of the good things and some of the bad.

First: the guns; the core part of any FPS. They're so fun to use in this game simply because they all feel different and it's very easy to recognize the differences between all the weapons. Stealth is also a big part of the combat, stealth takedowns and silenced weapons eventually become your best friend as rushing in is generally a bad idea (especially once you've reached the later half of the game) even on normal difficulty. Optional objectives are spread throughout the game which include: side quests, hunting challenges, sniper challenges and poker. Most of them are purely optional offering nothing more than something to do while you're playing others are higly incentivized (Radio towers, hunting, liberating camps + supply drops) as they offer XP, money and lead to unlocking better equipment and guns! Getting around isn't that hard either (provided you aren't getting shot at) and you'll find that once you have access to more fast travel points you'll reach your destinations really quickly!

Now I'll touch on the story for a bit before I get to the cons! The story... not so great! That is to say it's not amazing, but it feels a lot like an action movie and those don't really require great stories either! I did find, however, that across the story there were a few memorable characters and sequences that I really liked but the ending leaves a lot to be desired. Also worth noting, several instances of nudity!

And now the final part of this lengthy review, the cons! There were quite a few bugs, mostly visual and none of them game-breaking definitely a slight on the game but they can be over-looked! I found that when I was exploring or hunting for collectibles whenever I had a waypoint on my map there was no clear indication as to whther or not the thing I had waypointed was above me or below me. By the time I realized this this I had usually gone too far off to find the actual path to the thing I was looking for. And finally, the major offender... UPlay! I have nothing against the platform itself but not having it installed prior to playing this game lead to me waiting a good 45 mins before I could actually play the game. It also requires you to be connected to the internet for a enjoyable experience, meaning if you've got a dodgy connection or are simply having issues you should probably just play something else.

To wrap things up, like I said in the beginning, this game's great. If you have any interest in shooters or open world games then you have to give this game a spin, as there's tons to do and you'll probably have a good time doin' it!

reviewText:
Far Cry 3 is the best/worst game you will ever play.
It gives you a wide open world to explore at your pace, but only when it suits the game
It gives you plenty of side missions to complete in your own way, but they all have arbitrary rules that you need to follow.
It gives you a gripping story of a dudebro trapped on an island who lets go and makes his own way, losing his sanity in the process.
At the same time you will lose your sanity because while your free to do whatever you want, you can only be as free as the game lets you.
For examply, for arbitrary reasons the game restricts your progression until you've completed certain missions. Theres no real reason listed in the plot. Theres no gameplay stability that is disrupted in the gameplay that letting you level up however you want. The game has no reason to restrict you.
But it does.
Though I might sound a bit critical of the game, it really is fun. Its just also really stupid. REALLY stupid. I highly recomend it, but it has its quirks that don't make any sense.

reviewText:
Far Cry 3 is all about adventure, carnage, the jungle aspect and getting the best guns for your assault type. There are a lot of areas where FarCry succeeds but many more where it simply falls through the floor.

Far Cry 3 offers a compelling storyline through the singleplayer campaign. It is almost unrivaled and allows you to take hold of a person and watch them grow from a normal friend-loving schoolboy to a psuedo-psycho badass of the jungle.

Multiplayer is completely broken as there a lot of bugs and hiccups along the way. The loadout option is pretty much useless as there is currently one build that destroys anything else that you put against it.

Coop is a very welcomed theme within the Far Cry series, it's just a shame it wasn't implemented into the overall storyline. Or atleast contained within it's own world. Rather than you and a friend playing within the island sandbox, you are forced to go through objective-based and competition-based tasks that follow a very crappy storyline of 4 people just wanting to get rich and get out.

++ Singleplay, Multiplayer and COOP modes.
+ Guns and tools are nice
+ Great scenery
+++Buy this game for the singleplayer

- Multiple bugs
- Uplay requirements/overlay
- Game-breaking bugs
- Overpowered SMG class
- Graphics are similar to FC2 but..worse?

I would only recommend this game for the singleplayer and nothing else. The coop is fun if you're with the right people and playing on INSANE mode.

reviewText:
Far Cry 3 is the best/worst game you will ever play.
It gives you a wide open world to explore at your pace, but only when it suits the game
It gives you plenty of side missions to complete in your own way, but they all have arbitrary rules that you need to follow.
It gives you a gripping story of a dudebro trapped on an island who lets go and makes his own way, losing his sanity in the process.
At the same time you will lose your sanity because while your free to do whatever you want, you can only be as free as the game lets you.
For examply, for arbitrary reasons the game restricts your progression until you've completed certain missions. Theres no real reason listed in the plot. Theres no gameplay stability that is disrupted in the gameplay that letting you level up however you want. The game has no reason to restrict you.
But it does.
Though I might sound a bit critical of the game, it really is fun. Its just also really stupid. REALLY stupid. I highly recomend it, but it has its quirks that don't make any sense.

reviewText:
Far Cry 3 is a good game, a great game even. You could even say it's an excellent game. No game is without fault however I'll talk about some of the good things and some of the bad.

First: the guns; the core part of any FPS. They're so fun to use in this game simply because they all feel different and it's very easy to recognize the differences between all the weapons. Stealth is also a big part of the combat, stealth takedowns and silenced weapons eventually become your best friend as rushing in is generally a bad idea (especially once you've reached the later half of the game) even on normal difficulty. Optional objectives are spread throughout the game which include: side quests, hunting challenges, sniper challenges and poker. Most of them are purely optional offering nothing more than something to do while you're playing others are higly incentivized (Radio towers, hunting, liberating camps + supply drops) as they offer XP, money and lead to unlocking better equipment and guns! Getting around isn't that hard either (provided you aren't getting shot at) and you'll find that once you have access to more fast travel points you'll reach your destinations really quickly!

Now I'll touch on the story for a bit before I get to the cons! The story... not so great! That is to say it's not amazing, but it feels a lot like an action movie and those don't really require great stories either! I did find, however, that across the story there were a few memorable characters and sequences that I really liked but the ending leaves a lot to be desired. Also worth noting, several instances of nudity!

And now the final part of this lengthy review, the cons! There were quite a few bugs, mostly visual and none of them game-breaking definitely a slight on the game but they can be over-looked! I found that when I was exploring or hunting for collectibles whenever I had a waypoint on my map there was no clear indication as to whther or not the thing I had waypointed was above me or below me. By the time I realized this this I had usually gone too far off to find the actual path to the thing I was looking for. And finally, the major offender... UPlay! I have nothing against the platform itself but not having it installed prior to playing this game lead to me waiting a good 45 mins before I could actually play the game. It also requires you to be connected to the internet for a enjoyable experience, meaning if you've got a dodgy connection or are simply having issues you should probably just play something else.

To wrap things up, like I said in the beginning, this game's great. If you have any interest in shooters or open world games then you have to give this game a spin, as there's tons to do and you'll probably have a good time doin' it!

reviewText:
If you‚Äôre deciding whether to buy Far Cry 3 for Uplay or for Steam, I‚Äôd recommend you just get it for Uplay. Sure the Uplay client is inferior, but you‚Äôll have fewer problems getting the game to work (took a long time to get the game to run). Also, when you start the game in Steam, it just launches Uplay anyway so it‚Äôs basically just a shortcut. I had kind of a unique situation so I can‚Äôt say for certain that you‚Äôll encounter the same problems playing the Steam version

First off, the game is very hardware intensive. It probably stressed my system more than anything other than Watch Dogs, which I just gave up on running due to low frame rate. I had to turn down the graphics a bit to get a nice 40 fps for Far Cry 3. If you have better than a GTX 460 video card you should be fine.

For gameplay, the game is very similar to Far Cry 2 (big surprise). It‚Äôs a first person shooter with 4 gun slots (you unlock them through crafting). Similar to many other modern shooters, when you kill a gun wielding enemy, they usually drop that weapon for you to pick up, or just scavenge the ammo. There‚Äôs a stealth component to combat where you are rewarded (with extra exp) for sneaking up and using takedowns on enemies rather than just running in shooting. Various styles of takedown are unlocked through skill points as you progress through the game (such as dropping down on enemies or pulling the pin on an enemy‚Äôs grenade and kicking him toward his buddies. I mentioned crafting earlier and the crafting system is very simple, if somewhat time consuming. You hunt animals for their skins and use the skins to unlock equipment upgrades. For example 2 goat skins might increase the number of grenades you can carry or 2 flowers can be turned into a healing item. I spent about 3 hours just hunting all the animals to upgrade my gear before tackling the main story quests. Similar to Tomb Raider and Deus Ex: Human Revolution, ‚Äúleveling up‚Äù doesn‚Äôt make you stronger with more HP or damage. It just gives you a skill point to spend.

The game story is very well written and executed (completely new protagonist and story from the previous Far Cry games). I won‚Äôt spoil it for you but you start as a non-combatant and end up as a badass. There‚Äôs a ton of collectible items strewn across the game map telling the history of the island (kind of like Tomb Raider) and you‚Äôre rewarded for finding them with more exp.

Overall the game is fantastic and a definite thumbs up. I only have the basic version so I can‚Äôt tell you if the ‚Äúdeluxe edition‚Äù is worth getting. I kind of doubt it though. By the way, I thought Far Cry 3 Blood Dragon was a DLC for Far Cry 3. Blood Dragon is actually a total conversion and you don‚Äôt need Far Cry 3 installed (or even owned) to play it.

reviewText:
Good, but somewhat overrated


After all the praise I‚Äôve heard and read about Far Cry 3 I approached the game with some high expectations.
I had played ‚Äì and enjoyed - the original Far Cry. About the second Far Cry I read a lot of rather lukewarm comments and only purchased it on a Steam Sale  a year  or two later. As expected it was a mixed bag of an interesting open world gameplay (with an entirely different feel than FC1), but somewhat underdeveloped and riddled with annoying elements and a completely uninteresting storyline. Still I have to admit that somehow the game managed to keep my attention and I played it through to the end.

When I read about FC3 it seemed like once again a different kind of game than FC1 or 2. But once I started playing I found that FC3 is very much a continuation of FC2, but thankfully much better developed and with a lot of smart improvements.

The storyline is more interesting, the world is richer and more diverse and there‚Äôs a nice mix of gameplay elements to offer diversified gameplay experience. For the most part you can set your own pace, alternating between storyline missions and the various side missions to stretch gameplay and broaden up the experience.  Some elements, like the radio towers, were obviously adopted from Assassins Creed, but it‚Äôs a nice change of pace. The basic concept works quite well and gameplay all in all is enjoyable.

But while I thoroughly enjoyed the game some flaws and strange design choices kept FC3 from being a great game. Let‚Äôs ignore some of the weak spots in the storyline (and  skip over the pretentiousness of the ‚ÄúAlice in Wonderland‚Äù-quotes suggesting a depth the storyline simply didn‚Äôt have, and ignore the unsatisfying conclusion) and just look at the gameplay:

Crafting was basically an interesting idea, but I found it not all that useful and basically pointless in the second half of the game (Perhaps more useful on more difficult settings, but I played medium and don‚Äôt think I collected a single plant on the southern island). Money also is an important point in the beginning, but loses importance in the second half (most of the time I had more stuff to sell than my wallet could handle). I have the strong suspicion that shops originally should be spread scarcely across the map (as it was in FC2), but the integration of autoshops in most spawnpoints made shops pointless and gave gameplay a strange rhythm. That goes along with the quicktravel option, something I liked on one hand (especially later, when I hunted for relics), but it robbed the game some of its immediacy, since you could hop around the map (at least between unlocked points) and resupply as much as your wallet allowed. That‚Äôs the other extreme to FC2‚Äôs four travelpoints, which forced the player to travel long distances to missions. I would have wished for something in between: Less travel points, less (or even no) autoshops, no free weapons after radio tower missions.

And to be honest I found many gameplay elements repetitive after a while. Freeing enemies camp was fun most of the time, but many of the additional missions overstayed their welcome during the second half. IMHO it would have been smarter to introduce entirely new gameplay elements on the south island (if done smartly motivated by the different environment and enemy group). As it was the second half felt like ‚Äúmore of the same‚Äù and I found myself rushing through the missions.

Another missed opportunity was to integrate real sidequests. While inhabitants all over the map offer the player little sidequests, those have to be worked through immediately. How much more interesting it would have been to have quests, which can be accepted but finished either later, or might even have to be dealt with on a different spot on the map.

All in all FC3 was a definite improvement over its predecessor, but I can‚Äôt help but feel that some compromises and design flaws kept it from being even better. We will see if FC4 will correct some of those mistakes, but frankly as much as I enjoyed FC3 I‚Äôm not compelled to purchase FC4 immediately.

reviewText:
When I picked this game up in the sales for a few pounds, there was no way I expected it to be as brilliant as it actually is. Farcry3 follows Jason, a slightly wimpy American teenager who gets into trouble with some bad guys on an island. In essence, they kidnap some of his friends and he goes to get them back. Firstly, let's get the characters out of the way. Lots of people hate Jason and his friends, and although they are very 1 dimensional, I have to say I grew fond of Jason. His transition from cowardly white boy to tattooed warrior was a great development throughout the game. The other characters are brilliant; The unstable and unpredictable Vaas, in particular, I absolutely adored. And Sam. BLITZKRIIIIEG! I love the fact that you hear them referring to you as 'Snow White' as your legendary status increases, it makes you feel like a badass.

The game is just so much fun! I felt genuine fear as I ran and hid behind bushes from the enemies, having heard their trucks driving closer and closer. I nearly had a heart attack the first time a tiger jumped on me, and laughed out loud as a herd of cows chased me. I adored having to go to certain areas on the island to hunt for different animals to make things. The skill development trees are great, and the skills built up perfectly in sync with the difficulty progression of the game. The open world feature is brilliant - it makes the game less linear and a lot more interesting. I absolutely loved the idea of having to turn on the pylons to unlock sections of the map, and the turquoise water, sandy beaches and lush tropical vegetation make the game look stunning.

The tasks are varied and a lot of them are so much  fun  (the drug fields task was probaby my favourite task in any game, ever). From having to drive a quad bike against the clock, to sneaking into camps to take things, to shooting a gun and making everything explode from a helicopter, to torturing somebody, the tasks are endlessly entertaining. At no point in this game did I think 'oh great, another one of  these  tasks'. And that's another thing: you have a lot of choice. No, you don't have to keep taking out all the enemy camps, you can sneak around them. No, you don't have to do lots of vehicle driving if you don't want to. Aside from the main storyline, you can play the game how the hell you want.

The difficulty increases throughout the game so perfectly, you have to take your hat off to Ubisoft. Towards the end, the tasks got really quite demanding, and there were several instances where I 'ragequitted' and sulked for half an hour, before having to go back for more punishment. And to me, that is the sign of an incredible game - I had to finish it, I needed to know what happened. The storyline is probably the best storyline I have seen in a game for a long time, it flows well and you genuinely care about what happens.

Of course, there are a few bugs and general irritants in the game. The enemies are very 1 dimensional and often a bit daft, as Jason's friends are. Some of the later tasks are ridiculously difficult (constantly spawning enemies). Having to pat down dead bodies to steal stuff means you'e continuously having to hold E, and the character feels a little bit clunky when you're climbing around. Having said that, these are very minor issues that took absolutely nothing out of the game, I'm just trying to balance it out a bit.

I wish I could go back to the time before I played FarCry3 and start all over again. I absolutely recommend this game, and for the sale price of less than ¬£5 you would be absolutely crazy not to have this on your list.

reviewText:
Far Cry 3 is one strange game, on the surface, it appears to be a first person mash-up of Just Cause 2‚Äôs open world enemy outpost attacking and Tomb Raider‚Äôs ledge platforming/strange occult happenings on the Island. Yet when you dig a little deeper, you discover that it is exactly those things... with the main difference being that bows are less fun to use, as well as the absence of a grappling hook, lack of interesting characters or an understandable story and all those other things that tend to make games more enjoyable to play.

The story itself is pretty awful, you, your brother, his girlfriend, your girlfriend, your other brother and 2 other friends have all been kidnapped by a creepy mohawk guy who I can‚Äôt for the life of me remember the name of! You‚Äôll just have to escape and free the others. So begins about 8 hours of confusing alliances with yet more people with interchangeable names, during which, you rescue, one-by-one, your useless friends, who do nothing really to help you other than to comment on how heavily armed and tattooed  (sorry tataued?) you‚Äôve become. Speaking of tattoos, they are a rather interesting way of showing your progression through the skill trees, as with each new skill, you earn another tat, classy. Through the tense and action packed storyline, you get to meet, among others, an American guy who likes flamethrowers, a really creepy Australian guy and an even creepier woman who likes wacky rituals‚Ä¶ These ‚Äúcharacters‚Äù, apart from all being completely psycho, contribute to help or hinder you as you travel ‚Äúyour path‚Äù of revenge against the Mohawk guy from the beginning. I personally didn‚Äôt really want revenge on this guy, much preferring just to go home, but that‚Äôs alright, because I don‚Äôt have to make those sorts of decisions! The only real choices you get in this game are pretty much just relegated to what weapons you get to carry, which in some cases is cut down by having to carry a plot-significant heavy weapon like a flamer that my long range sniper build didn‚Äôt need.

In between my character‚Äôs illogical decision making, the game actually gets fun. Generally, you‚Äôre allowed to leave the plot missions for a while and go explore which typically involves climbing defunct radio towers to reveal parts of the landscape (something I think was done better in this title than Assassin‚Äôs Creed!), then finding the nearest pirate outpost and taking it over. Whilst I‚Äôve read a lot of praise for this part of gameplay, (which is undoubtedly fun), I rarely found it necessary to scout out and silently kill all the guards to avoid setting off the alarm, since I tended to forget about that and charge in with a HMG armed technical, mowing down even armoured pirates with ease. Besides, when you‚Äôre in a vehicle, dogs, leopards and angry cassowaries can‚Äôt hurt you!

The animal life in the game is pretty cool, with all sorts of deadly creatures out to get you, including but not limited to snakes, crocs, tigers, bears and tortoises - although the tortoises are about as deadly as a speed-bump (which I often used them as, sorry cuties...). Aside from the fact that these animals seem to be armoured and unless strictly classified as ‚Äúprey‚Äù will not scatter when shot, instead preferring to go out in a blaze of glory and charge me, they seem pretty realistic, and it always adds a bit of fear to wandering off the roads into the jungle (which I do not recommend if in a vehicle).

The vehicle handling is pretty well done, although like in FC2, the available choices are usually limited to different coloured jeeps and technicals, with the rare cargo truck or buggy scattered around the place. That‚Äôs not to say the devs haven‚Äôt tried to make each technical look different, I was particularly impressed by the different rust patterns and colours I found, at times wondering whether any of my weathering pigments could approximate that hue‚Ä¶ they won‚Äôt if you‚Äôre wondering.

Overall, the game is pretty good, but I‚Äôm left feeling a little sickened after the main storyline, since mutilation isn‚Äôt really my thing‚Ä¶ Other flaws contribute to making elements of the game just painful. For instance, I was constantly getting stuck when running on stairs and other small rocks in the ground, which if I was playing battlefield wouldn‚Äôt be a problem (come on this is basic stuff, even for a 2012 game!). The extremely cluttered hud with massive text reminding you of your objective was also pretty distracting, bring back FC2‚Äôs minimalist one! Thankfully, once the main story is complete, you can free-roam to you heart‚Äôs content, so I may still play it for that, but the flaws do add up, so I definitely would not recommend paying full price for the game, the fact that it got GOTY awards when others from 2012 like ME3 didn‚Äôt really surprised me. I‚Äôd say definitely play it, just get it in a sale first :D

reviewText:
Outstanding. This game is a truly epic role-playing first-person-shooter. It's what others call, 'Skyrim with guns.' In my opinion, a must-own game that deserves a 9/10.

Story: You are a guy named Jason Brody who he and his friends go on vacation on an island known as The Rook, in which get captured for randsom, and now you need to free them and get off the island alive.

Gameplay: In an open-world island filled with exotic creatures and menacing enemies, players are given the ability to survey and plot their attacks when it comes to danger; with either stealths, such as silent takedowns by performing melee attacks from above, below, or close behind, or just sheer brutality like taking an RPG and shooting explosive objects. Equipment is controlled by a simple system: Missions get completed, new items are unlocked to be purchased or crafted. Skills are are unlocked in three skill trees, collected by gaining experience from simply killing enemies or doing missions.

Pros:
+Organic gameplay.
+Layered narrative.
+Great story.
+Can be modded the crap out of.
+Has multiplayer.
+Has co-op campaign.
+Awesome guns.
+Amazing characterization.
+Amazing graphics.
+Moving soundtrack. Doesn't beat Skyrim's, but it's awesome.
+Fantastic single-player campaign.
+Upgrade system and character progression is astounding, featuring experience points, skill trees, and a crafting system.
+Ecology and unpredictable creatures make the world vivid.

Cons:
-Can get slighty repetitive.
-Quick-time events.
-Too many in-game cutscenes, leaving little to no control over your character.
-Some boss fights sucked.
-Unrealistic upgrade system. I mean, come on, tattoos make you stronger?
-Side characters, meaning Jason Brody's drug-loving, alcohol-drinking friends, are ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing arrogant.
-Like most other free-roam RPGs, this gets boring upon completion of the game.
-Co-op mission design feels lackluster.
-You need the right rig to play this game.
-Ubisoft's Uplay.

reviewText:
This time, world renouned jet ski enthusiast Gaston Broley may have gone too far! Fueled by alchoholic fervor and being able to do the robot, he has punched out some chinamen, gone skydiving, and gotten himself into trouble with some priates who killed his brother who would have been a better protagonist in every way. Can a drunk, worthless, ex roadgeneral's spoiled brat son/ex marine corps POG provide him the career guidance he needs to overcome evil? Will visiting the shaman chick ever help his quest in a meaningful way that doesn't involve boobies? Is there any problem that can't be solved by waving an LMG around until hundreds of people are dead? We shall see, shan't we gentlemen?

Going to start with the positives, the game is fast paced and fun except when you are hunting animals for necessary supplies, which unfortunately is the whole first half of the game; the controls are responsive and make sense even if it keeps ommitting the lean buttons it arguably would be better for; the stealth and cover systems are good and don't use any consoley gimicks like sticky cover; the gunplay has depth in general as soon as you get used to the fact that the ballistics make no sense and AK47s somehow don't kill deer when you shoot them right through their vitals; the weapons are distinct and balanced and have cool upgrades but still only do damage if they aren't full auto; the game retains the original sequel's good storytelling via animation, patting fire out, biting bullets, most of the scripted combat, and ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• like that are all very gritty and hillarious, and stuff like shooting or standing too close to a wall makes you pull your gun back realistically which doubles as a cover/stealth indicator; and the characters are well acted. The two guys who help you out and advance the plot, both white americans, although one of them is also at the same time a hillarious german steriotype that keeps helling BLITZKRIEEEEEG, are very likable and relatable in their psychopathic this is a fart cry game sort of way. Also jumping is satisfying for some reason.

Hang glider is arcadey but satisfying and grounded in actual concepts like dumping altitude for airspeed, the wingsuiting and parachuting is ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•t by about 1000 feet of ground clearance and opening the parachute somehow makes you actually stop and go upwards for a moment. If you go over a little hill, you can glide down somehow like it's the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing moon. Like every non urban open world game which also lacks random encounters, the driving around adds very little other than making you reload your save when you keep driving off a cliff trying to make the driving sections not seem so ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing long and dying.

Jason can for some reason stab a billion guys super fast once you level him up a little because he is the great white tribal hunter, but in all the other ways you can think of he's just like the guys from fart cry 2. That is a big difference though, and it IS fun sometimes. The window to cutscene stab someone when they have not raised their weapon or you have just sprinted up to them is also pretty satisfying, and unlike human revolution, its not actually a cutscene stab, it's really fluid and barely breaks up the action at all.

Sadly the finale is pretty lame, you basically just get really good at killing and shoot up an airfield and then do a stupid but not too challenging rail shooting mission, hardly the exposive and challenging finale of fart cry 2 that forced you to kill all your fellow ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• expatriots, and very very short indeed of actually good finales like those of Mafia, F.E.A.R., Max Payne, GTA IV, etc.

Also unforunately when I say that the animation is good, I mean it is good except that stabbing animals is somewhere between the walking dead and fighting goo men with a lightsaber, and slashing people to death makes you wonder why broley hasn't broken his wrist flailing around and limp wristing like that, I sense a trend, it is people who don't give a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• about how things actually get stuck in things as long as you get a nice closeup, maybe that's also why fall damage breaks the hands instead of the legs so that you can akwardly set them while holding them up to the camera. It's like they took far cry 2's animations' bitter sense of realism, as well as it's dark absurdist sense of humor, and while retaining them added a bunch of random stuff they thought was cool like extreme sports, whining girlfriends, and obnoxious edginess and racist exoticism for no reason. With the slashing animations I mean, I think the fall damage was also that dumb in fart cry 2. And also they actually did all those things to the story too.

Not all the characters were good, Citrus and Dennys seem like they were not given their fair share of the cameratime as originally intended by the writers, this is because they advance the plot in no way for two reasons. The villagers are ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing useless and don't help because otherwise they would have had to make AI that's good, and the named characters are useless because fart cry now serves two very different masters, as in fart cry 2 they need to make all the assistance you get have a blackly humorous price tag or come for a blackly humorous ironic reason, but on the other hand, I think it would seem racist or break their stupid exoticist mystique, not sure which, if the entirely colored cast of named tribesmen (all two of them) were actually humorous or interesting. Still, if they, and bandito king, honestly, he also came off as half baked, had been given more chracterization than maybe they would be likable and the protagonist's personal struggles might actually make sense. Hell, even coke dealer just seemed like a 3 edgy 5 me crazy person added only to advance the plot, with a paperthin connection to the initial premise, whose worldview we don't really trust at all.

Buck, I think he got enough characterization, he just, he just likes ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•.

Also why do you kill bandito king and buck with the china blade but you kill coke dealer with his own knife, I had been led to believe that using the china blade was like the whole point of those psychadelic knife fight scenes.

I'll go ahead and spoil the ending because nobody likes the main character anyways, all the white people are really nice to him but the exotic islander chick and the drunk black dude declare that he needs to kill them because they are racist or something and nobody ever chooses that because it's ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• and makes no sense, so the black dude drunkenly tries to kill you, accidentally killing her and surprising nobody, why didn't he ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing die though? What a useless sack of ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•.

I give it a meh +, the plus is because the guy on the cover has good trigger discipline. It's depressing that this passes for good these days, but at least I can play something to fulfil my need to shoot people dead.

Also, if Crysis broke all of Fart Cry 2's teeth out as the better sequel, than this game knocks Crysis 2's internal organs out by lightly flicking it in the toe as the better threequel. For a game that is literally just mixing Fart Cry 2 and ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• Creed and coming out worse than both, it is actually really fun and complete.

Is it better than alpha protocol? Worse story, worse tech tree, better gameplay. Similar mediocrity that gets saved by lovable sociopaths. And I don't mean bandito king, bandito king is boring not lovable. Before playing either game play all three Stalker games, Crysis, and Fart Cry 2, those are all better.

I also can't reccomend the game if you hate white people or white people being the hero of a game about pacific islanders, unless you like white people killing their loved ones in order to join a racist steriotype islander tribe of course. Unless you have that particular fetish you won't be choosing that option at the end.

!!! Far Cry 3 !!!

Hmmm...Game Of The Year 2012? Yeah, I'm 2 years behind on this game and i cant believe i let this one slide me by. Let me start by saying it's refreshing to meet a game where it's strongest point is singleplayer, usually current games stash all of their real content into multiplayer then hack on some half-witted single player just to have it there.

First off, just to get it out of the way, you have to deal with the horrible abomination that we all call Uplay...I'm glad i could finally play the game in offline mode, but still, it's a dumb program in the way of your gaming experience. reviewText:
Far Cry 3 was one of my favorite games of 2013.

As with the previous Far Cry games, we have always expected them to be a PC gaming benchmark graphically and this game is no exception. The graphics are excellent, and can bring high end gaming machines to their knees! However, even with a mid range graphics card you could easily manage some playable settings and enjoy the game to the end.

The characters are quite easily the best part of this game. Vaas is possibly the greatest villain ever portrayed in a game, largly down to immaculate voice acting & believable animations. Even the side characters you meet on the way are believable and help immerse you in the story.

Controls are easy to get to grips with whether you use keyboard or control pad. I played through with an Xbox 360 controller and it was an enjoyable experience start to finish. The feeling of the guns is realistic and they feel different whether using a pistol of LMG, the weight and control is spot on.

Overall the game is immaculate and shouldnt be missed. It's a shame the PC multiplayer seemed quiet because I thought it was brilliant, some nice game modes, excellent maps, and the graphics are still on point. Better than the typical CoD games. Did not get a chance to try Co-op but from what i've seen it seems fun.

I would give the game 9/10 for single player alone, could have been 10/10 if the multiplayer had been able to extend my time with this game!

reviewText:
When this game first came out, someone said that it is like Skyrim with guns.  I think that's generally a fair assessment.

It was a bit frustrating that some of the missions required stealth since I don't think this game was trying to be a stealth game.  I really liked being able to boat around and I was terrified of swimming in the open oceans due to the sharks (it felt rather real).  The upgrade system was a bit foreign to me since I hadn't seen perks implemented as they were in this game, but it didn't take long to figure it out.  The injections system by which you crafted stuff like health vials and a few other buffs was a bit awkward and I don't think it added much to the game (although it was a necessary thing to do in order to play successfully).

I had fun playing it.  I don't expect to play it again, though.   I'm a bit excited to give the previous FC games a try, though, once I work through my backlog a bit.
