reviewText:
Outstanding. This game is a truly epic role-playing first-person-shooter. It's what others call, 'Skyrim with guns.' In my opinion, a must-own game that deserves a 9/10.

Story: You are a guy named Jason Brody who he and his friends go on vacation on an island known as The Rook, in which get captured for randsom, and now you need to free them and get off the island alive.

Gameplay: In an open-world island filled with exotic creatures and menacing enemies, players are given the ability to survey and plot their attacks when it comes to danger; with either stealths, such as silent takedowns by performing melee attacks from above, below, or close behind, or just sheer brutality like taking an RPG and shooting explosive objects. Equipment is controlled by a simple system: Missions get completed, new items are unlocked to be purchased or crafted. Skills are are unlocked in three skill trees, collected by gaining experience from simply killing enemies or doing missions.

Pros:
+Organic gameplay.
+Layered narrative.
+Great story.
+Can be modded the crap out of.
+Has multiplayer.
+Has co-op campaign.
+Awesome guns.
+Amazing characterization.
+Amazing graphics.
+Moving soundtrack. Doesn't beat Skyrim's, but it's awesome.
+Fantastic single-player campaign.
+Upgrade system and character progression is astounding, featuring experience points, skill trees, and a crafting system.
+Ecology and unpredictable creatures make the world vivid.

Cons:
-Can get slighty repetitive.
-Quick-time events.
-Too many in-game cutscenes, leaving little to no control over your character.
-Some boss fights sucked.
-Unrealistic upgrade system. I mean, come on, tattoos make you stronger?
-Side characters, meaning Jason Brody's drug-loving, alcohol-drinking friends, are ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing arrogant.
-Like most other free-roam RPGs, this gets boring upon completion of the game.
-Co-op mission design feels lackluster.
-You need the right rig to play this game.
-Ubisoft's Uplay.

reviewText:
When I picked this game up in the sales for a few pounds, there was no way I expected it to be as brilliant as it actually is. Farcry3 follows Jason, a slightly wimpy American teenager who gets into trouble with some bad guys on an island. In essence, they kidnap some of his friends and he goes to get them back. Firstly, let's get the characters out of the way. Lots of people hate Jason and his friends, and although they are very 1 dimensional, I have to say I grew fond of Jason. His transition from cowardly white boy to tattooed warrior was a great development throughout the game. The other characters are brilliant; The unstable and unpredictable Vaas, in particular, I absolutely adored. And Sam. BLITZKRIIIIEG! I love the fact that you hear them referring to you as 'Snow White' as your legendary status increases, it makes you feel like a badass.

The game is just so much fun! I felt genuine fear as I ran and hid behind bushes from the enemies, having heard their trucks driving closer and closer. I nearly had a heart attack the first time a tiger jumped on me, and laughed out loud as a herd of cows chased me. I adored having to go to certain areas on the island to hunt for different animals to make things. The skill development trees are great, and the skills built up perfectly in sync with the difficulty progression of the game. The open world feature is brilliant - it makes the game less linear and a lot more interesting. I absolutely loved the idea of having to turn on the pylons to unlock sections of the map, and the turquoise water, sandy beaches and lush tropical vegetation make the game look stunning.

The tasks are varied and a lot of them are so much  fun  (the drug fields task was probaby my favourite task in any game, ever). From having to drive a quad bike against the clock, to sneaking into camps to take things, to shooting a gun and making everything explode from a helicopter, to torturing somebody, the tasks are endlessly entertaining. At no point in this game did I think 'oh great, another one of  these  tasks'. And that's another thing: you have a lot of choice. No, you don't have to keep taking out all the enemy camps, you can sneak around them. No, you don't have to do lots of vehicle driving if you don't want to. Aside from the main storyline, you can play the game how the hell you want.

The difficulty increases throughout the game so perfectly, you have to take your hat off to Ubisoft. Towards the end, the tasks got really quite demanding, and there were several instances where I 'ragequitted' and sulked for half an hour, before having to go back for more punishment. And to me, that is the sign of an incredible game - I had to finish it, I needed to know what happened. The storyline is probably the best storyline I have seen in a game for a long time, it flows well and you genuinely care about what happens.

Of course, there are a few bugs and general irritants in the game. The enemies are very 1 dimensional and often a bit daft, as Jason's friends are. Some of the later tasks are ridiculously difficult (constantly spawning enemies). Having to pat down dead bodies to steal stuff means you'e continuously having to hold E, and the character feels a little bit clunky when you're climbing around. Having said that, these are very minor issues that took absolutely nothing out of the game, I'm just trying to balance it out a bit.

I wish I could go back to the time before I played FarCry3 and start all over again. I absolutely recommend this game, and for the sale price of less than ¬£5 you would be absolutely crazy not to have this on your list.

reviewText:
Let me start by saying I'm not usually someone who enjoys FPS games but I think to call FC3 simply an FPS would be wrong. Although the storyline and setting is pretty typical of FPS games (bad guys/terrorists vs you/the little guy) the gameplay its self isn't typical. Infact, the game rewards you for trying outlandish, improvised or tactical approaches to seemingly ordinary objectives.

You'd think all this freedom means it's just another one of those titles that you derp about blowing yourself and everything else up till you get bored and leave the game to rot in your library, but the storyline and characters within FC3 do enough to make you want to actually finish or at least progress through the game. The map itself, teamed with the crafting mechanics and ecosystem, is great fun to explore. The little relics and hidden locations mean getting sidetracked can be worthwhile. I personally also really enjoy the patrols of bad guys and having to hide or engage, which is just another way the game has of reminding you not to relax for too long.

There are a few things that annoy me however. Firstly, you need a Uplay account to run this. I bought through Steam because of the convienience and achievements and all that cool stuff, but Uplay wipes that out. There are a few UI/Navigational annoyances in this game too, menus mainly. Some of the flavour texts I feel are a little overdone, or repeated too often to be funny. These are however more preferential things than a straight up issue.

In short, even if you don't play FPS games, you'll still probably enjoy this enough to warrant picking it up through a sale. Good fun.

This is a very difficult game to review, I'd like to note before we begin that this is my opinion with my OWN experiences... you may think the problems I found with it to be nothing or you may just not like me bashing your wonderful game but I'm speaking or in this case typing from the heart, any stupid comments will be ignored including those that wish totell me how gay I am or how much of a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• my mom is.

Now onto the review shall we?

This is a very fun game... I stayed up 2 and a half days straight to complete it but there is really nothing to do but the story and that lacks so much...

This is not a game like GTA, it offers a wide variety of extra tasks to do but there is no need to do them other than to feel the grind, one extra is the ability to hunt to craft upgrades and the ability to find flowers to create medicine or buffs but I completed the game without upgrading any of my gear and I never had to create buffs... the only thing worth while creating was medkits and once you unlock the ability to heal yourself without medkits(much slower) you will not find the need for them... I also never really ran out of ammo and if I did I just picked up another gun off an enemy.. easy!

I also hated the weird magical mystical scenes.. granted when I'd smoked some weed or had hallucigenic powder blown in my face? great! but then you reach say a boss battle and your transported to some made up magical place where the fight consists of button bashing (really.. you have to mash keys when it tells you to win) at first I did not even know I had killed the first boss.. I thought I was somehow on drugs in fact I still believe I was on drugs.. Now I had great fun with this game but I don't know I'm sort of half for recommending it and half for not... right now it feels a cross between original farcry but done as a point and click adventure game..

I've decided after a small break to decide that I'm NOT going to OFFICIALLY recommend this game however I'd like you to be well aware that this is a magnificent game even though there was to many flaws for me to recommend it.. you should buy it if it's affordable to you.. I recommend this game but I don't, 5/10 (meet you half way)

reviewText:
I just can't put this game down. It is just too immensely rich and fun to play. There is always a cave you haven't explored, a secret you didn't find, a nice place you didn't see, a way of fighting you didn't try before... Rook Island always makes you come back for more.

Gameplay--- I have to place this statement in a proper context though. My first playthrough on the vanilla version of the game only lasted about 25 hours, full of high-tempo combat, mad driving, killing pirates by the dozens, completing missions in a hush-hush way. This is because the original game can feel a little FPS-mainstream (damn you, COD, for what you have done to the genre). The emphasis is a little too much on the action, and less on the open world and side missions, as is the case with Far Cry 2. However, where game-dev's fail in order to satisfy the producers and the company, the game community comes to the rescue. With proper modding (Ziggys Mod!), this game becomes what it had to be all along. The pace is slowed down, the difficulty has gone way up, making run-and-gun console-type approaches impossible. Instead, you have to resort to guerilla-warfare and the use of stealth and your natural surroundings. The over-guidance of the vanilla game is gone; you have to rely on your own noodle now. Sometimes you'll be the hunter, sometimes you'll be the prey, and that is what makes this game an exciting experience. Also, you will notice that this game is much richer in content than you noticed at first, since you spend too much time running and gunning in the vanilla version. Now, you can just ignore the missions and go hiking the amazingly beautiful island on your own.

Storyline--- Although I get the feeling that it is a little too clich√©-ridden, the storyline is quite decent. No big plot twists or big schemes, but enough to keep the game going, and to give you a sense of urgency. Also, it does a good job in letting you question your morality and sanity by the end of the game, a nice break from the justified-violence themes in other games in the FPS-genre (yep, looking at you, COD). The most credit has to go to the voice-actors, who did an incredible job in giving the characters some depth (Vaas already is a classic).

Technical aspects--- The graphics of this game are just insane (keep your finger on the print-screen button!). Then again, so are the system specs, even for current standards. Bear this in mind when you buy this game!

Multiplayer and coop--- Not really worth the trouble. The multiplayer is COD-clone without depth (sorry for the fanboys that I keep mentioning this franchise in a negative way). The coop, however, is quite fun and easily accesible, since it uses a sort of 4-player drop-in format like L4D. But honestly, who cares? This is the best single-player experience I had!

Conclusion--- Buy it, mod it, fall in love with it. Once you set a foot on Rook Island, you'll never want to leave.

reviewText:
Far Cry 3 is an open world first person shooter set on a series of island in which you can travel to each by boat.

The game features a superb storyline for a first person shooter and involves what became one of the most beloved villains of all time, Vaas (A psychotic killer who is constantly hunting you throughour the game).

The mechanics of the game are smooth and the game has high replayability. As you guide the main character through the horrors of the jungle, you will also help him grow into a veteran warrior.

You will go from being the hunted to being the hunter. This is possible only through 3 major things within the game:

Firstly, the game's character progression system. As you level up, you will learn new abilities which enable your character to gain health, speed, killing blow moves and the like.

Secondly, the game's crafting system. Collecting items will enable you to craft certain items which can be used to buff your combat abilities or empower you in other ways.

Thirdly, the game's weapons. The game has a large variety of weapons. Be the silent hunter of stealth or run and gun your way to the top!

The game has a decent sized campaign with tons of content packed in. It's the blockbuster experience this game offers that makes it so beloved.

The optimization is great, there are tons of options to fiddle around with to fit your specific needs as a gamer. So don't be afraid, if you're looking for an explosive vacation to the tropics, look no further - Far Cry 3 has you covered.

reviewText:
I‚Äôll probably never finish playing FarCry3.  The game suffered from front-loading all the best content.  The first half of the game was superb.  The second half failed to live up to what preceded it.  On almost every level ‚Äì villains, objectives, scenery, atmosphere ‚Äì the second half of the game was like a bad sequel.  But what finally drove me away was utter disgust for the character I was required to play.

Unlike a lot of games that try to implement moral choices and some sort of moral system, FarCry3 seemed utterly uninterested in whether what the character was doing was good or right or heroic, instead choosing to focus on other themes.  This was ultimately to the game‚Äôs detriment, as progressing in the game often required acts that were morally unpleasant ‚Äì just because the game designers don‚Äôt particularly care if something is moral or not does not mean that the players won‚Äôt.

For example, the opening of the game did a wonderful job setting up the pirates as a force that I could wipe out in good conscience ‚Äì they were horrible, sadistic and murderous men who made me feel like I was saving lives when I removed them from the gene pool.  Even those who may not have been so downright evil were enemy combatants in a war they had chosen to declare on me.  And the game did a good job reinforcing this with many of the random encounters.  Absolutely none of that can be said for the mercenaries introduced midway through the game.  I expect this was intentional.  The game makes a point of claiming it is about insanity, and this is a fair way of showing the character‚Äôs increasingly murky morality and perverted mentality.  But in choosing to do that, the game chose to create a protagonist whom I found progressively less enjoyable to play.   Inevitably, the game‚Äôs demand that I mass-murder a huge swath of these guys was more than I was willing to give it.

I'll admit, my attitude towards wholesale slaughter of the mercenaries probably had a lot more to do with the game than an objective measure of their comparative evils.  Hoyt himself was certainly as bad or worse than any of the pirates; and the mercenaries were following his orders, right?

When the mercenaries first appeared, I had no idea who they were.  It was a mission to provide sniper cover for my allies while they attempted to recover their people whom the pirates had taken prisoner... or so I was told.  Except the people who showed up weren't pirates.  All I knew about them was that they looked military -- for all I knew, they were the armed forces of a sovereign nation, or possibly even people sent in by the United Nations -- and that they decidedly weren't the people I was there to shoot at.  I didn't know these people, I had no grudge against them, I couldn't even be sure that they weren't the good guys, and I had absolutely no reason to declare war on them.  Except that if I didn't the game would not allow me to progress, so it was either murder these people for no good reason or quit the game.

I continued playing, despite the really bad taste that left in my mouth, because the game had been amazing up until that point.  Next, I find out that instead of the allies I was told I'd be rescuing, the military men were transporting my enemy.  So either my allies had suffered a catastrophic intelligence failure, or I had been lied to.  Worse, I'd just declared war on an unknown group and murdered a bunch of their people in order to set a horrible, sadistic psychopath free... for all I knew, I'd just launched an attack on the good guys just as they were taking action against the pirates!  To say I was unhappy was an understatement.  I had lost every bit of faith in my allies" and I really wanted to be given the option to tell them to go ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• themselves.

Of course

reviewText:
Far Cry 3

You've been captured by pirates, and it's up to you, Jason Brody, to rescue your friends and get the hell off the island. As action heroes go, Brody is an unlikely one. While Far Cry and Far Cry 2's protagonists had military or mercenary backgrounds, which at least explained their ability to reload an assault rifle in three seconds, you're just an over-privileged Californian bro in his early twenties stuck in a nightmare situation.

Far Cry 3 is one of the best open world games ever.
This game offers a wide variety of different things to do, From Liberating Outposts to even hunting animals for their skins! Far Cry 3 is a delightful and harsh tropical wonderland, crawling with wildlife and threatened by the pirates and drug runners that disrupt its peace. Furthermore Far Cry 3 also has multiplayer, co-op so you can play online with friends or just play a game of deathmatch , Far Cry 3 also has a map editor where you decide what you want in your map, from where you want the animals etc...

When i got Far Cry 3, i thought it was going to be another typical First Person Shooter game but i was wrong, Far Cry 3 adds realism to the game which actually makes you feel as if you are Jason Brody yourself. Far Cry 3 is a game i would definitely recommend to people who love fps games but  WARNING: THIS GAME HAS ANIMAL ABUSE SO IF YOU ARE A ANIMAL LOVER THEN THIS GAME IS NOT FOR YOU . I would give Far Cry 3 a 10/10 for many reasons, one of them being the graphics which is just out of this world and the characters are well created especially Vaas who is my favourite character in the game simply because of his humour. To the people who do not own this game or don't have the sufficient funds for it, wait for the sales to come around then Far Cry 3 will drop prices massively and that's when you can get it but if you do not own this game, you are really missing out.

What i don't like about this game are the constant notifications and reminders. These are so frequent, and so annoying, like if i am roaming around, nearly every 10 seconds a notification pops up on the top corner of the screen about the objective which can get a bit annoying but that is all that i have against this beautiful open world fps game.

reviewText:
What a massive game this is. Huge islands to explore with just too many sidequests. You can just run/drive/fly around and do nothing or you can; hunt animals, craft items, free settlements, find relics and other secrets, take over radio towers, do some trials and a whole lot of other activities and (side)quests. It's seemingly endless and completing the entire game will take you probably well over 50 hours. Now that's some value right there.

The graphics are just gorgeous, no matter what settings you use. You can't make this game look bad, you just can't. The animations and models are some of the best I've seen in a game. Wow. The same thing applies to the sounds and voice acting, which is brilliant and truly convincing.

While doing the story and sidequests you'll earn XP to upgrade your skills. There are 3 skilltrees in total and the way you play the game is entirely up to you. The Shark skilltree will let you upgrade your assault and healing skills, while the Heron tree will help you with your sniper skills and speed and finally, the Spider tree will let you focus on your stealth and survival skills. There's no right way to play this. There are many ways to complete an objective. And that's what makes Far Cry 3 fun, but not necessarily unique.

However, there aren't many FPS that give you this much freedom, while telling a realistic, focused, story at the same time. So I take my hat off to Ubisoft for creating this masterpiece. The commercial and critical success for this game is well deserved.

Let this be a lesson - and example - for future first person shooters. Hooray for Far Cry 3 !

[Rating: 92/100]

reviewText:
I've played about 30+ hours of Far Cry 3 on PC and another 40+ hours back on Xbox 360, meaning I've had quite some experience with the game. That being said, Far Cry 3 is probably Ubisoft's prime example of advertising and hyping without fully delivering, hence my negative review: it's far from as great as people claim it to be.

The Good:
¬∑ Michael Mando's performance as Vaas Montenegro is very well done, simply one of the best motion capture in any game.
¬∑ The huge island allows for hours of exploring, hunting, and doing sidemissions.

The Bad:
¬∑ First I'm going to list what bothers me the most, and it also happens to be the thing I liked the most... Vaas. Ubisoft promoted Far Cry 3 with Vaas from the get-go; putting him in the early demo, placing him on the boxart, including a wahini-figure in the Collector's Edition... his insanity was basically the center of the game. Unfortunately, those promises weren't met. Slight spoiler warning ahead so please skip to the next point if you don't want any bits of the story given away, but Ubisoft's oh so glorious Vaas Montenegro had a combined total screentime of 15 minutes. Yep. Durning your 30+ hours, only 15 minutes will be spent looking at or listening to Vaas. It's like buying a movie ticket to go and see Fight Club just to end up watching A Good Day to Die Hard.
¬∑ The missions are repetetive beyond believe. Save this person, do this for that guy, kill these guys. The sidemissions exist largely of racing- and huntingmissions, both equally boring after the first time. The only enjoyable mission -- spoiler warning, again -- was the one where you had to burn marijuanafield with a flamethrower to a raggae-dubstep beat. If only there were more original missions like those.
¬∑ The character development is so unbelievable it feels parodic at times. You go from a party-going teenager to a hipster Rambo that is able to murder hundreds of experienced soldiers in a few hours.
¬∑ There's no real reason to craft anything. Health syringes are useless if you have upgraded your manual healing skill that'll automatically heal you when you're out of syringes (by bandaging your scratched arm when you fall or pulling out a bullet when a tiger attacks you. Yeah...) Your wallet can only hold a certain amount of money, so maybe crafting a larger wallet would be usefull. But why do so if climbing all the radio towers will basically get you all the weapons for free?

The Visuals:
¬∑ The overal graphics are very nice, from detailed textures to great lighting, but the shadows were so overdone it almost felt cartoonish.

Final verdict:
¬∑ High expectations, even higher promises, and ultimately you get an avarage repetetive shooter. Far Cry 3 is the best example of how Ubisoft spends more time hyping and advertising than polishing what could have been a much better product. 6/10

reviewText:
This game is amazing with a great story, amazing visuals and really good shooting mechanics.

Gameplay-

The shooting mechanics in this game are brilliant. The guns feel very nice to use and there are a lot of different types to use. Enemies can shoot through thin walls which is both realistic and amazing, and cover is done really well too. If you hide behind something you can aim down the sights and you will lean out or fire over the top.

Scattered across the map are radio towers and enemy strongholds. Radio towers are useld like veiwpoints in Assassins Creed, where you have to go to the top and trigger an animation to be able to veiw that area on the map. Another bonus to these is that you get some really nice veiws from the top. Unlocking radio towers unlocks free weapons in stores, so you never have to pay a large amount for a gun. Enemy Strongholds can be taken out by lots of different ways, stealthily stabbing everyone, sniping all the pirates or just running in all guns blazing (which is likely to get you killed).

There are several different vehicles in the game to get you from A to B. They are really fun and feel nice to drive with a keyboard and the handling is very arcade-y. There are also 3 types of boat and handgliders scattered across the map for fun transport. Enemies and friendlies will patrol in these as well and some really fun situations can emerge where you find an enemy roadblock and try to run from it, only to be pursued by two cars filled with pirates.

The first part of the game is very survivaly as you are unequipped and have low health. Hunting and crafting are used to improve your equipment and skills are used to improve yourself, such as adding more health, not running out of stamina and being able to hold your breath under water for a lot longer.

I would reccomend playing on hard or very hard difficulty otherwise the game just becomes too easy within about an hour.

The Map-

The first half of the story takes place on an absolutely stunning jungle island. It is absolutely huge and is covered with stuff to find. Temples, outposts and caves dill the map with stuff to do. The second half of the game is located on an island about a kilometre south that is made up of mountains and to me, wasn't as impressive. It was still very good but there just wasn't as much stuff on it to do but the outposts and enemies there are a lot more challenging, so that's fun.

Story/Missions-

The story missions ranged form burning fields of weed with a flamethrower to shooting pirates to exploring ancient tombs in search of a treasure. The characters are really well written and the voice acting is brilliant. After completing the game there are still many side missions to do aswell as hunting activities and bounty quests. However, one of the biggest problems with the game becomes apparent during the missions, the checkpointing. Sometimes it is fine but other times you will die and be reset to 5 minutes earlier, that becomes annoying.

AI-

The AI is very good, especially on the higher difficulties. They react to sounds and their dead bodies and don't just look for you for ten seconds and then stop, they will keep on searching. Also, they don't just follow paths, their movement seems very dynamic and don't patrol a small area on a repeated loop.

Graphics and Sound-

On a GTX 760, intel i5 4690 3.5GHz and 8GB RAM, I get about 60FPS in 1080p and everything at ultra, apart from a few things which are at high. The game is beautiful and colourful and the FOV goes all the way up to 110, which is better than most games (ahem Skyrim).

The sound is brilliant aswell and the way enemies react to sounds feels real. If htey hear a gunshot they will search in the direction it came from to find it. All weapons have a unique sound that is very luad, like a gun should be, unlike other games where an assualt rifle sounds like a cough.

Overall-

The game is amazing and really fun. The checkpointing is the only real issue I have with it but otherwise it is brilliant.

reviewText:
Amazing open world first person shooter with survival elements implemented.
The vegetation is dense and well-detailed. The vehicles are varied and feel satisfying to drive.

The Co-op multiplayer, however, is completely different to the hunting-survival-like single player.
Co-op gameplay reminds me of Left 4 Dead (but without the zombies). You and 3 friends run and gun your way through set paths blasting and shooting absolutely everything in your way. There are even mini-games where you compete against your friends to get the most points.
It's a bit different from the single player, and can provide a breath of fresh air if you are bored of sneaking around in the bushes stalking a tiger in order to craft a larger wallet or whatever.

The Versus multiplayer is like any other first person multiplayer game- not much to say here apart from there are some playlists which include custom maps made by the community which is a nice addition. (did I forget to mention there's a level editor included with the game?!)

Overall, a brilliant game that can fill all your first-person shooter desires.
There are some mods online which can tweak your single-player experience to make it more realistic and emphasise the survival aspect of the game, as well as make the weapons more realistic (ie: more deadly).

reviewText:
With the (at the time of writing) recent release of Far Cry 4 I think the best way to sum up Far Cry 3 is ‚ÄúStill entirely relevant‚Äù

Far Cry 3 is a beautiful game and an absolute joy to play. The atmosphere and the vibrancy of the island you have at your disposal is such a wonderful contrast to most games with the First-Person Shooter classification. One of the most compelling parts of the Far Cry formula is the freedom to approach a situation in whatever way you can dream up. As a fan of stealth games, my mindset was to wipe out an entire enemy force and either make it look like a tragic accident or a nightmarish ninja slaughter. Another aspect that oddly sticks out in my mind is the guns; they all sound unbelievably real and deadly. I‚Äôm not sure how they crafted the sound effects for gun fire but they nailed it in Far Cry 3.

So again, my best summary of Far Cry 3 is still ‚Äúvery relevant‚Äù. It is a fantastic open world, first-person, sandbox shooter with light RPG elements and I highly recommend everyone pick it up while it‚Äôs cheap!

reviewText:
I finally bought this during the 2014 holiday sale. I'm playing the hell out of Far Cry 3 and really enjoying it, but holy ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•, it's completely indefensible. A real shame, because the game is really fun and well designed.

Problematic themes and depictions include:

A raging case of Last Samurai Syndrome. A white man comes to an exotic foreign world and is quickly adopted by the oppressed natives not only into their culture but as their savior, despite the fact that he knows nothing about their environment and has no applicable skills. We're supposedly a tribe of island warriors who've been living here since time immemorial but only you can save us, scrawny Californian douchebro who's never handled a gun before!

As such, the Rakyat can't do anything for themselves. Only Whitey Samurai has any kind of power in deciding how the Rakyat fight for freedom. After the heroic white boy singlehandedly liberates an enemy outpost, a half dozen Rakyat warriors show up in jeeps to secure his conquest, AK47s at the ready, but they're only there for atmosphere. They're unable to take outposts themselves or even help the hero out. I know that having the player be the only being in the world with agency is a convention of open world games going back farther than GTA, but it's pretty ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ed that these people literally have to wait around for the white hero to save them.

Citra. The spiritual leader of the Rakyat is a colonial fantasy straight out of Victorian pulp fiction, the hypersexual female native drawn to the white savior, despite being surrounded at all times by hunky warriors from her own culture. Weirdly, she doesn't even look like she's the same ethnicity as the other Rakyat, who are supposedly... Polynesian? (The game never says exactly where Rook Island is.) Citra is ethnically unplaceable, and definitely has more caucasian" features than the rest of her people

reviewText: Of all my 23 hours so far - not one has been boring, dull, or not played to its full. Seriously, other open-world games do not even come close to this, yeah, GTA is the most popular because of its diversity and gameplay, but the survival and adventure feel of Far Cry 3 tops most other gaming experiences I've ever had. Alike other games, this also comes with a fair amount of bugs or mechanics that could be improved on - like the steam overlay bugging out as seen in my screenshots, or when skinning an animal you're really just skinning the floor. But in my opinion with the gameplay and emotion that comes with this game, I can totally forgive every single one of its small errors. If you have the money, don't hesitate for a second to buy this game. I'd give a 9/10 in terms of gameplay, graphics and content.

reviewText:
A gorgeous game, sandbox-ish game where you are a jungle warrior instead of just having a vacation.

I say sandbox-ish, because while you can do other missions and activities than the main story, it feels like it's not that much that you can do and half of it feels the same.
That said, this game is certainly not bad. Actually, it's really good.

The story goes where your friends, brothers and you go on an exotic, adventurous vacation. What they didn't saw coming was that you all would be captured by swashbuckling pirates who want to sell you for ransom money. That is certainly not what the brochure said...
You manage to escape and you have to find and safe your friends and brother.
All in all, it's pretty good but it has some flaws of which mostly: Character Progression.

The game starts as you, scared and unexperienced. Never killed a man before but the moment you get a weapon in your hands, the main character goes pretty much berserk. While it is understandable that you can't limit the skills of the player, the story doesn't make this progression better and soon you will be the Berserker Warlord of the Jungle.
It has potential but it goes just a bit too fast to believe it.

Gameplay feels smooth and feels right. From the firefights to the stealth, nothing to really complain there.
There really is a bunch to do and terrain to see and it looks damn good.

The biggest problem I had with Far Cry 3 is that the Field of View returns to default in cutscenes, making it look like every character is invading your personal space.

All in all, a beautiful game with a name story and lots of things to do!

reviewText:
A very good sandbox FPS, although with some detracting elements in my personal opinion. The islands are pretty damn well made and there has been time and effort spent in building a believable backstory, history and culture for the Rook Islands.
The game running and shooting mechanics are also pretty good, where you won't instantly shoot if you are running and switching between weapons feels believable, along with the sliding mechanics which are worth a mention. There are also a nice amount of weapons to choose and unlock from. The enemies are also nice and varied and can pose a challenge if you stay exposed too  much.
The story itself is not bad, but maybe it is me, I just felt I expected what would happen before they happened and found most story elements too predictable. Another thing which actually ended up bugging me is that throughout my game session I probably killed enough tigers to have reduced the overall worldwide tiger population by a wide percentage margin. Tigers, leopards and bears you encounter should in my opinion have been more rarer. And bull-sharks are ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•s, I happily rammed them with my jet skis whenever I could.
I also feel the Skills system was very redundant in many places, with abilities that were hardly useful, but also some which should have been unlockable earlier (You unlock your skills three times throughout the story, having one set of skills available in beginning, another set further in and then last set of skills a good way into the game).

I would still recommend the game, as it is quite fun and if you spot it at bargain price, get it. I would advice though that while it is Steam, it will start up Uplay, but not been that much a hassle really.

reviewText: Beautiful graphics are just not enough to turn this game around. These are the positives: responsive controls with customizable keyboard configuration that actually works (funny that I have to call that out, but many games execute this poorly), good graphics, and a large, often interesting area to explore. If that's enough for your gaming experience, then this is the game for you. If you like multiplayer, also, this is a great setting. However...\n\nIf you want a good single-player game, unfortunately, Far Cry 3 also has these things that I have to put in the negative column: really, really annoying major and minor characters (including the main character Jason, who must be the all-time worst ever created for a shooter - bad, whiny voice acting combined with no redeeming values), an awkward game interface for controlling inventory and crafting (obviously designed entirely for clunky consoles), endless messages popping up on the screen to tell you things that you already know or don't care about, poorly executed big game hunting" that is both cartoonish and annoying
date: and worst of all: every major villain must be dealt with in some kind of "alternate-reality" setting that seems to be happening in the unlit hallways at Ubisoft. Note to game designers: every time you move someone abruptly out of the game world you have been carefully creating for them for the last dozen hours
recommended:
you ruin the immersive experience. Boss fight with Vaas? Lame. Boss fight with the weird Australian guy? Lame. Boss fight with Hoyt? Lame. Boss fight with the giant island demon thingy? WTF? Lame.

Half-way into this game I absolutely lost any interest at all in how it would turn out and finished it entirely so I could expunge my disappointment by shooting a few more pirates. I give this game a 5 out of 10.

reviewText:
Like Far Cry (and not so much like the somewhat disappointing Far Cry 2), Far Cry 3 is a stunningly beautiful game. It's also loads of fun to roam around, do crazy things, blow stuff up, kill people and endangered species. The side quests are fun, too, and generally satisfying.

The weak point of the game is really the story and the main quest line. I read an article where the story writer argued that those criticising the story hadn't understood it. Well, if you need to explain the story, it wasn't told very well to begin with. What's left is posturing, trying to defend poor storytelling abilities.

There are games that tell their stories very well; Valve are particularly good at that, starting with Half-Life. GTA4 is another example, where you know that Niko Belic did some pretty bad things back in former Yugoslavia, but it never becomes specfic, and it doesn't need to be.

Then, there are other issues that take away from the fun. The game occassonally crashes, and if you're in the middle of a long mission, well, though. You'll have to start all over again. It happened to me at least five times.

Cut scenes cannot be skipped. There are a couple of examples where it's quite easy to die, and every time you have to watch the same boring cut scene again. And again. And again.

Which brings me to dream sequences. For some obscure reason, some game publishers are under the illusion that dream sequences are cool. They're not. They suck very, very much.

Some parts of the game are very dark, even with brightness and gamma all the way up. I need a bit more light than the average gamer, but I just can't crank it up enough to see everything. Maybe if I had a super bright TN screen, but no, it's eIPS. And other games don't have the same issue.

Finally, a dishonourable mention goes to Uplay, the Ubisoft launcher that you get without asking for it. Whatever the idea behind this piece of annoyware is escapes me. Maybe they're trying to create some sort of brand loyalty; they achieve exactly the opposite. Steam serves me just fine. I don't need another layer.

So, would I recommend this game? In a word, yes, as long as you get it on special offer. It cannot be stressed enough how gorgeous it looks (as long as you're outside at least), and there are so many fun things to do. The weak story is something you have to accept as part of the package.

reviewText:
Far Cry 3 was described as 'Skyrim with guns'. Despite the immediate similarities with Skyrim, I'm afraid this is totally not the case and Far Cry can stand on it's own as a game set on such an island. The Far Cry 2 engine can clearly be seen at work here despite the fact that it is updated and there are new animations that make the experience feel a whole lot better. The great things about Far Cry 3 remain its excellent shooting mechanics and driving, the gameplay really sells the game itself as it is a joy to actually shoot a gun and kill people within Far Cry. Each gun feels very responsive and though it could use some tweaking, the actual gunplay is quite rewarding and fun, making you feel like a rising killer within the game. The story however is a total let down within this game. I found the main character, Jason to be quite annoying and unlikeable really and part of this was due to the poor voice acting of his character in comparison to many of the supporting characters such as Vaas, Buck and Willis. Vaas' performance was incredible and made me really like him as an antagonist within the game and he truly was as frightening and crazy as I hoped upon seeing the trailer for the game. Despite the fact that the story was a let down and really wasn't very clear, it does have decent character development as Jason (whom never shot a gun before) starts to like killing and murdering people. I actually felt as if I was this character and due to the excellent shooting within the game, I also started to like killing people within the game.

The island itself is very diverse and has a variety of different landscapes and areas to explore even after completing the main game. The multiplayer, I hadn't really delved into so much though I'm sure it would be as generic as many of the other first person shooters.

Overall, I would give Far Cry 3 a 7/10

reviewText: Aside from being gorgeous this games environment is quite flushed out. Be it animals running around, predators trying to eat you, random ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• exploding, or pirates trying to murder you, this game always has something for you to do. As far as FPSRPG's go, I think this has some of the best gunplay I've experienced for a while. It feels impactful, and the gun sound assests make it sound that way as well. That being said sometimes powerful animals/enemies in the game can feel a little bullet spongy, which isn't really something I liked. The side-quests can get quite boring and  are mostly monotonous busy-work, though it can be made up for a by the plethora of side activies and challenges you are able to do. (i.e. poker, shooting challenges, races, or capturing outposts)\n\nIn short, the world is great to run around in, the combat is satisfying, and the story is great (whether you take it literally, or put your own philosophical theory to it). Does it have some downsides? Yes, but what game doesn't? This game was definitely worth it, and I'd recommend it even if it were still a full-priced title.

reviewText:
Great game!
9/10 in the BlacKy scale.

The good:

* Story starts great (no spoiler): A group of rich kids went for a vacation on an exotic island (or a group of islands if u'd like) to have fun, but then gets kidnapped by pirates. You free yourself and get help from local villagers to free your friends and take the kidnappers down.

* Island looks amazing. Overall graphics is very up to date.

* Exploring the island is very fun (whoever liked Red Faction Guerrilla's enviroment will like this aswell). Many side quests to do. Having a bunch of items to find (just like the classic hidden boxes from the GTA series). Driving a vehicle makes you feel as you're inside the game. You can actually feel bumps on the road.

* The wildlife is very nice. Many exotic animals to encounter. Animal's AI is well done overall.

* The more you advance in the game, enemies get thougher.

* Customizable weapons. Need i say more?

* Co-op is pretty fun when its not crashing.

* You get to cheat on your gf with an amazonian nympho.

The bad:

* Story ends bad, in my opinion: I'll do my best not to spoil - When having the chance to get out of the island with all your friends, you take the other option, revenge, staying behind and killing those who have kidnapped you and your friends.

* Enemies AI is a bit poor. They sometimes suspect that something is wrong but they dont tend to do much about it, even if they're defending an outpost, etc.

* I've found all the syringes except health syringes to be unnecessary to use. No need to dive too much underwater so water syringe is irrelevant. The camera's ability to tag enemies and animals makes the hunter syringe to be irrelevant aswell. You can extinguish fire when you're on fire so fireproof syringes are, again, irrelevant.

* Your health is too OP. You can make up to 10 health packs while also carrying impossible amount of crafting materials to make even more health syringes if you'll need to use later. After getting enough progressed in the game, you have constantly infinite amount of health which makes everything boring and less exciting.

* The skill tree isn't as good as other games, E.G Borderlands franchise. You will eventually unlock all the skills in the game, which makes it unnecessary to think 'which skill am i going to unlock next?'. Some of the skills have absolutely no value in the game so you may think that even if you have free skill points to spare, you wouldn't pick that specific skill.

* While the crafting option itself is very well made. Everything craftable in the game gets unlocked after ~50% of game time (finishing the north island), so you wont be needing to kill animals for hides at the second island at all if you have explored the first island effectively enough.

* Activating radio towers makes the game very easy. Too easy i might say. Weapons will become free in weapon shops, ammo gets very cheap, and you get the sense that money isnt a factor anymore. If you like a bit of a challenge, dont do what i did, which was unlocking most of the radio towers before making the quests. Try exploring everything at once:

- Do a few missions.
- Do a few side missions.
- Explore the island as you can: Find some artifacts / SD cards / letters / etc.
- Unlock some radio towers and outposts.
- Repeat

* uPlay - Sadly this game runs by uPlay, which means constantly-crashing servers in multiplayer and co-op, no Steam achievements, and no real option to search for specific servers like in normal Valve servers via Steam.
Multiplayer and co-op have no skill filter. A level 1 noob will often join a group of level 75's (highest level).

The ugly:

* Vaas

Overall:

I admit i was 'letting myself go' on the bad stuff. But when you play the game, you will realize the good compensates the bad in many ways. Very enjoyable game. Open world FTW!
Just dont count on the MP / Co-op to be enjoyable. Because of the above circumstances, its not.

reviewText:
You know that bitter sweet feeling you get after finishing a really brilliant book or tv series? That desire to know more about your favourite characters after the events of the story, you feel accomplished for getting to the end, but at the same time, you don't WANT it to end.
That's how this game made me feel. It is rare for a first person shooter to have a really compelling story, with a protagonist you care about and an antagonist you love to hate. Play Far Cry 3 and delve into the world of insanity in Jason Brody's transformation from scared helpless tourist to bonified badass.
Get passed Uplays awfulness and get immersed in one of the greatest open world shooters I have ever played.
Did I ever tell you the definition of insanity?
It's not playing this game.

reviewText:
A great game with a not-so-great story.
Far Cry 3 has a very solid gameplay aspect to it. I love roaming around the jungle, gathering plants for potions, hunting animals for their skins and upgrading my equipment and killing mad baddies. I love activating the radio towers for more weapons and to reveal more of the map and I love trying to unlock the signature weapons. I enjoy that the collectibles that aren't impossible to find, but that's not my thing really. If you enjoy them, you'll like this game. The gun's are awesome, and for once, the melee isn't useless if you know when to use it! I played this game through on hard and the difficulty was perfect for me, as I died multiple times, but still felt like I was making progess. Except some times when it throws you back 5-10 minutes on a really hard mission multiple times, but fortunately this is very rare.
Now the story on the other hand is very basic, and after about 2/3 through the game it get's dreadfully boring. You'll see why. But if there is one thing I love about the story it's one character. The character who single-handedly saves this game's story. Vaas, the main villain, a maniac pirate who loves to tell you the meaning of insanity. Sadly the other characters are boring or just plain annoying (except for Dennis, he cool mang.) This game's advertised as a game that breaks the rules of story-telling games' cliches, but honestly it follows many of them. Except every once in a while it throws some crazy-‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• riddles at you that go away so quickly you don't even have time to think them through. And the ending, in my opiniion, is the worst thing since Shaquille O'Neal's acting career, but some people think it's fine.
Even after that rant I still enjoyed this game a lot, and you can see I played it as a single-player game even though it has a multiplayer aspect to it. So if you're into that, this game has it too!
I'll give this game a 8/10 for it's amazing gameplay and Vaas.

reviewText:
This was the game of the series that I had heard the most about from reading reviews and whatnot. This is the first game where I‚Äôve actually found real enjoyment from playing it and I‚Äôm so glad that most of my biggest issues with Far Cry 2 were extinct when I played this one. For once, I‚Äôll actually be talking about how good the game is and just not relentlessly bash it.

In this game, your character Jason Brody and his friends were on vacation and after skydiving over a random island get captured by natives/slavers. You escape and have to explore the island, rescue your friends, and help the natives, the Rakyat, deal with pirates. It‚Äôs a simple premise, but it definitely works. The island is beautiful. This is by far the best looking game in the series so far. It‚Äôs exciting to wander around seeing all the various plant life, the waterfalls, and everything else the island has to offer. It‚Äôs a gorgeous game.

This is once again an open world shooter, which means you can approach missions however you like. Once the game finally gave me a sniper rifle with a silencer attachment, I was unstoppable. There are outposts you can clear of pirates all over the island, and for me, all I would do is snipe all of them and go undetected most of the time. Unlike the previous game, when you clear out an outpost, the Rakyat warriors move in and hold the outpost, and there will be fewer to no pirates spawning in the area ever again. This was one of my top 2 problems in Far Cry 2 eradicated. Awesome.

The wildlife‚Ä¶what can I say? There‚Äôs a variety of wildlife that you can hunt, or be hunted by, for you to collect pelts to craft upgrades. The crafting system is pretty good, letting you create things to restore health, enhance senses to detect enemies or wildlife, increase ammo capacity, or carry more money. As for the wildlife, there‚Äôs goats and deer, as well as more exotic creatures like komodo dragons and tigers. Tigers are really annoying to deal with if you run into them a lot early in the game like I did, but it keeps you on your toes and keeps your twitchy trigger finger happy. If you feel slightly less adventurous, you can just hit the animals with a vehicle. This was the best method I found to reliably kill skarks, using the propeller blades of the boat to decimate them. I ended up getting most of my upgrades done pretty early in the story.

There‚Äôs a couple types of side missions you can do, such as hunting rare animals, knife assassination missions, types of racing missions, and various others which I haven‚Äôt really tried. Aside from the hunting the rare animals to get all the best upgrades, I didn‚Äôt really bother with doing other side missions because they just weren‚Äôt all that interesting to me, and I got bored of them pretty quickly.

There‚Äôs a skill system which is solid. You get xp from kills and missions and everything just as you would expect, and when you earn skill points from getting enough xp, you can put points into one of three skill trees to increase things like your survivability, how fast you can reload, boost accuracy, new types of takedowns, and all sorts of things. There are few skills I would call useless which makes deciding where to use skill points all that much harder.

I think my only major problem with this game is that the stupid, inhumanly smart AI from both of the previous games is back, and god is it annoying. I tend to use weapons with silencers on them so that I can stealth kill from afar. Yet when I happen to miss a shot just barely, or even when I kill someone who was near another enemy, they know exactly where to look for me somehow. How? Do they just happen to automatically know the bullet trajectory? It makes sniping a little bit harder, and on one particular outpost, clearing it out this way was just impossible, and I had to clear out waves of reinforcements before finally claiming it for the Rakyat. Also, AI pixel perfect accuracy is still bull.

Far Cry 3 is the game that finally gets me to genuinely like the series. The only real frustration I had was caused mostly by my own incompetence rather than bad game design, which is definitely good. It improves upon everything that made the previous two games unique and/or good, and for me at least, finally made the game enjoyable. Everything is better, the wildlife is a unique challenge at times, the story is interesting, and the game is just gorgeous.

TL;DR Best game in the series so far, with few major flaws

8/10
Awesome

reviewText:
Far cry 3 is a very good game in general and you can visibly see all the good game design decisions.
Its setting is a strong point- showing off just how well the developers worked to create a living-breathing environment that you can become completely immersed in. Graphically, it is very aesthetically pleasing but can be very taxing on older machines.
Gameplay-wise it mostly fluid and intuitive, with a good, solid movement system and shooting mechanics designed for fast paced but skillful shooting. However it came become a pain to quickly move in and out of vehicles and healing yourself can become a serious pain.
Few games can claim to have a story I've given 2 half-baked waffles about but Far Cry 3 has quite a good story. With engaging charater arcs and plot twists that twist the plot for once. The story is all very tight and works well with the rest of the game.
However, while I don't want to spoil the ending too much, it's one of the only parts where the game lets itself down.
The final mission of the game is split two ways - Flying from the enemy base in a helicopter to 'Ride of the valkyries' in an epic mounted turret section- then going through some boring tibal love drama nonsence. Then you pick if you want to be with your friends and escape or with Citra- the tribe leader. Its a sort of moral choice sequence with no moral choice. The 'friend end' is the only real end as the other one just ruins most of the stories believeability.

reviewText:
TL;DR- Far Cry 3 manages to improve on its predecessor without abandoning most of its basic mechanics. Does have a ridiculous plot that is terribly handled at the end.

I had a love/hate relationship with Far Cry 2. I loved the weapons, the world, and the combat. But I hated the way the place was populated only by people who wanted to kill you on sight (except for in the closed cities). I didn't like the way enemies respawned automatically and the beautiful world was somewhat marred when I couldn't enjoy a senic boat ride without getting sniper fire, even though I'd crushed that outpost five minutes earlier. Unlocking weapons tended to be a bit tedious as well, though it was worth it to get some of the best ones. The mortar in FC2 is one of my favorite weapons in ANY game. It took patience to figure out, but once mastered it could be used to desolate an enemy encampment in dramatic fashion.

FC3 keeps the nice variety of weapons, with the facepalming exception of the above-mentioned mortar. I guess it was unbalancing because of how useful it could be against outposts, but I still wish they had left it in somewhere. Vehicles are still fun, as are boats, plus handgliding is actually a bit more doable in this game- even useful when the game doesn't cheat and turn on the invisible walls for missions. Best of all, not everyone is out to kill you at all times. There are different factions in the game and only MOST want to kill you at any one time! You can actually see battles between the different factions where you can help one over the other. When you take out an enemy outpost, it stays down... unless you decide to revert them back to enemy control so you can have fun blowing them up again- a neat option by the devs to placate both sides of the 'respawning enemies' argument. Plus they've added carnivors. If you remember in FC2 they made some kind of hand-waving statement that they couldn't do that because it would wreck the simulation... or something. Well this time they said screw it

reviewText: For those of you who haven't played it, this game deserves hours of your life. I gladly spent hours of mine on the PS3 version, and have downloaded it on my PC to play through again on a harder setting and see the full potential of the graphics. This game is absolutely beautiful. The PS3 version had me impressed, PC has my mind blown. If you want to immerse yourself in a game that both feels and looks real, this is it. Graphics aside, the story starts you out on a skydiving adventure (no gameplay) that goes horribly wrong. You wake up in a cage with your buddy and have absolutely no idea what is going on, aside from the fact that some insane dude is talking to you from outside the cage. His name is Vaas, and you'll be working towards taking him and his regime down for the entirety of the game. He is one mental badass. The rest of the game involves taking over enemy camps, hunting animals, securing radio towers and powering them on which unlocks better weapons/ammo/attachments. There are various quests to do as well that will unlock things. It's a great set up, and you feel as though you become a part of the village you started in. I'd also add that the themesong is amazing and I have to listen to it more than once every time it comes on. There are some good songs throughout the game, but there's also the typical FPS-esque ones that drone on without any real melody. To me this game gets a 9/10. It's almost perfect. I cannot wait to see what Far Cry 4 is going to bring to the table.

reviewText:
Great game!
9/10 in the BlacKy scale.

The good:

* Story starts great (no spoiler): A group of rich kids went for a vacation on an exotic island (or a group of islands if u'd like) to have fun, but then gets kidnapped by pirates. You free yourself and get help from local villagers to free your friends and take the kidnappers down.

* Island looks amazing. Overall graphics is very up to date.

* Exploring the island is very fun (whoever liked Red Faction Guerrilla's enviroment will like this aswell). Many side quests to do. Having a bunch of items to find (just like the classic hidden boxes from the GTA series). Driving a vehicle makes you feel as you're inside the game. You can actually feel bumps on the road.

* The wildlife is very nice. Many exotic animals to encounter. Animal's AI is well done overall.

* The more you advance in the game, enemies get thougher.

* Customizable weapons. Need i say more?

* Co-op is pretty fun when its not crashing.

* You get to cheat on your gf with an amazonian nympho.

The bad:

* Story ends bad, in my opinion: I'll do my best not to spoil - When having the chance to get out of the island with all your friends, you take the other option, revenge, staying behind and killing those who have kidnapped you and your friends.

* Enemies AI is a bit poor. They sometimes suspect that something is wrong but they dont tend to do much about it, even if they're defending an outpost, etc.

* I've found all the syringes except health syringes to be unnecessary to use. No need to dive too much underwater so water syringe is irrelevant. The camera's ability to tag enemies and animals makes the hunter syringe to be irrelevant aswell. You can extinguish fire when you're on fire so fireproof syringes are, again, irrelevant.

* Your health is too OP. You can make up to 10 health packs while also carrying impossible amount of crafting materials to make even more health syringes if you'll need to use later. After getting enough progressed in the game, you have constantly infinite amount of health which makes everything boring and less exciting.

* The skill tree isn't as good as other games, E.G Borderlands franchise. You will eventually unlock all the skills in the game, which makes it unnecessary to think 'which skill am i going to unlock next?'. Some of the skills have absolutely no value in the game so you may think that even if you have free skill points to spare, you wouldn't pick that specific skill.

* While the crafting option itself is very well made. Everything craftable in the game gets unlocked after ~50% of game time (finishing the north island), so you wont be needing to kill animals for hides at the second island at all if you have explored the first island effectively enough.

* Activating radio towers makes the game very easy. Too easy i might say. Weapons will become free in weapon shops, ammo gets very cheap, and you get the sense that money isnt a factor anymore. If you like a bit of a challenge, dont do what i did, which was unlocking most of the radio towers before making the quests. Try exploring everything at once:

- Do a few missions.
- Do a few side missions.
- Explore the island as you can: Find some artifacts / SD cards / letters / etc.
- Unlock some radio towers and outposts.
- Repeat

* uPlay - Sadly this game runs by uPlay, which means constantly-crashing servers in multiplayer and co-op, no Steam achievements, and no real option to search for specific servers like in normal Valve servers via Steam.
Multiplayer and co-op have no skill filter. A level 1 noob will often join a group of level 75's (highest level).

The ugly:

* Vaas

Overall:

I admit i was 'letting myself go' on the bad stuff. But when you play the game, you will realize the good compensates the bad in many ways. Very enjoyable game. Open world FTW!
Just dont count on the MP / Co-op to be enjoyable. Because of the above circumstances, its not.

reviewText:
Far Cry 3 is a mixed bag. I've enjoyed it thoroughly, but it seems to be one of those games which provides a lot of things to the player, but doesn't do any of them particularly well. I bought the deluxe edition version of this game for ¬£5, so I'll happily admit that it's a steal; I do think it's been worth my money, however.

Good pointsThe AI is much better than in Far Cry 2 - multiple playstyles are actually an option now, rather than being forced to go rambo for each of the outposts in the previous game
Graphical-wise, it is a very pretty looking game. The forests look quite lush and the upgrades to the engine help compliment this, even if the ambient occlusion seems pretty strong at times
There is actually a story that you can follow this time. To me, Far Cry 2's story seemed pretty nonexistent, so this is a large improvement
A much wider diversity of weapons compared to its predecessor, and the attachments and paintjobs let you customise firearms to suit your style
Much of the bad points in Far Cry 2 have been addressed and built upon, for instance outposts respawning if you venture a couple of meters away and the driving physics is much better
Bad pointsThere's only one environment in the game, and it's the jungle. I understand this was remedied in Far Cry 4, but it does make it slightly dull when the entirety of both islands are the same
Once you've completed the game, there isn't much to do other than free the remaining outposts and complete the side quests - which personally, aren't that interesting
Overall, I'd recommend you purchase this, but I'd wait until it's next on sale.

reviewText: Beautiful graphics are just not enough to turn this game around. These are the positives: responsive controls with customizable keyboard configuration that actually works (funny that I have to call that out, but many games execute this poorly), good graphics, and a large, often interesting area to explore. If that's enough for your gaming experience, then this is the game for you. If you like multiplayer, also, this is a great setting. However...\n\nIf you want a good single-player game, unfortunately, Far Cry 3 also has these things that I have to put in the negative column: really, really annoying major and minor characters (including the main character Jason, who must be the all-time worst ever created for a shooter - bad, whiny voice acting combined with no redeeming values), an awkward game interface for controlling inventory and crafting (obviously designed entirely for clunky consoles), endless messages popping up on the screen to tell you things that you already know or don't care about, poorly executed big game hunting" that is both cartoonish and annoying
date: and worst of all: every major villain must be dealt with in some kind of "alternate-reality" setting that seems to be happening in the unlit hallways at Ubisoft. Note to game designers: every time you move someone abruptly out of the game world you have been carefully creating for them for the last dozen hours
recommended:
you ruin the immersive experience. Boss fight with Vaas? Lame. Boss fight with the weird Australian guy? Lame. Boss fight with Hoyt? Lame. Boss fight with the giant island demon thingy? WTF? Lame.

Half-way into this game I absolutely lost any interest at all in how it would turn out and finished it entirely so I could expunge my disappointment by shooting a few more pirates. I give this game a 5 out of 10.

"

On the other hand story is so much bull after few first missions that i stuck mainly to side missions when ever possible. Whenever drug induced hallusinations or massive power dreams come to play all the realistic feel is drained from game. This makes games atmosphere really sway too much to enjoy. Maby cooperative mode will redeem this game for me, but i won't play story ever again.

Serious review: Far Cry 3. I've played Far Cry 2 before on Xbox 360 and liked it, but got bored since all the missions are essentially the same. Go somewhere shoot it up, occasionally die of Malaria. But this one I played every day since I had it download. Let's start with pros, neutrals, and cons.

~Pros
+Variety. The missions vary from hunting some animals to killing a bunch of dudes while ziplining to them, and trying to blow up a bridge with an RPG at the same time.
+Graphics. Stunning graphics, even on the lowest possible settings.
+Music. So much amazing music, specifically Beethoven.
+GUNS! SO MANY GUNS! AAAAAAHAHAHHAAHHAHHAH!

+Wingsuit. I'm not telling you about this. You get to find out on your own.
+Vehicles. In Far Cry 2, the vehicles were smooth, but they were even smoother in this game.
